Sir,

Your letter No. 19687-5 of Aug. 13th received enclosing blue print. We have marked the location of the teacher's residence on the lot, which runs between No. 3 and No. 5, 100 ft. and fifty feet back from the road.

If the authority to go in and make the repairs to the building comes in time, Mr. Butler expects to be able to have it ready for the teacher by the 1st of May next. Meanwhile there being no place for him to board back there and stay out being a holiday leaving only four listing days in next week, we gave permission for him not to start tomorrow till the following Monday.

In reference to the distribution of lands which we talked over with Mr. Stewart, the lands in question are No. 6 and No. 7. No. 6 has been drawn to the Fosse lot. J. Fosse sold his right to it to Mrs. Fosse and moved to the Amargosa Valley. She rented the land to Bennett Eisehans. When he died last year it was left vacant as his lease had expired. The former owner with families wanted land and offered to pay for improvements thirty-five dollars each. George Smith paid thirty-five dollars cash for half of it, and Mr. McLean gave a three months note for the other half. The latter man is going on Bennett Eisehans' property, and he having had possession for some little time is not satisfied and claims some of the land.

Lot No. 8. When J. Perry's wife died he gave up his land, and the tract was moved off. Mr. Harlow, again at that time gave Frank Perry possession of it. When Mrs. Fosse died Frank came into possession of her lot and gave up his right to No. 8. Therefore Butler gave a three months note for half of this lot; on which note he paid $25.

Trusting this is satisfactory and awaits your further orders.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Indian Agent's Office

Bridgeport, N.S.

Ottawa, September 6, 1917.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, returning the blue print showing the location of the lot purchased from Osias Beeler, on which the building for a teacher's residence at the New Germany School is situated.

In reply I beg to say that a cheque for $50.00, being the price agreed upon for this lot, will be sent Mr. Beeler.

With reference to the repairs required for the building, I beg to say that you may make the necessary arrangements with a competent carpenter to have this work done and the total expenditure incurred by you to have these repairs made should not exceed the estimate given by you in your letter of the 6th of August, namely, $120.00.

You should forward proper vouchers in duplicate for the material supplied and the labour required in making these repairs.

These repairs should receive your prompt attention, in order that this building will, as soon as possible, be put in a suitable condition for the teacher to reside in.

Your obedient servant

J. D. McLEAN

Ottawa, October 11th, 1917.

Madam,

I beg to enclose herewith voucher for $119.93 drawn in favour of O. Beeler for repairs to the teacher's residence, and I have to draw your attention to the fact that H. A. Nader's account of $26.92 and L.S. DeLong's account of $5.30 are not receipted. It is necessary that these accounts should be receipted or the Department furnished with separate accounts in their favour and cheques will be issued direct to them. If this course is followed, the two above accounts should be deducted from Mr. Beeler's account of $119.93.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Mrs. N. P. Freeman,
Acting Indian Agent,
Bridgewater, N.S.
He visited the New Germany school a few days ago and saw the teacher's residence, which is satisfactory excepting the need of some paint for the walls and ceiling which are sheathed and which will separate and warp if not painted. Mrs. Ford says if the department will provide the paint she will paint it herself.

She also wished us to write the department about providing wood for the house, one store, cabinet from up fire cords used too much. She can get it for six or seven dollars cut up.

We investigated Mrs. Henry's case and find that she has some crop and is not at all destitute. There are a few little things needed for the school house and residence, three pieces of glass, a shield for the stove pipe, and zinc for under the stove. I shall try to procure them.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, and in reply I beg to say that the Department is not prepared to supply any paint for the teacher's residence in connection with the New Germany School.

You may purchase five cords of wood for the teacher's residence and the cost should not exceed the price you quote, viz., $6.00 or $7.00 a cord cub. up.

You may also purchase the three panes of glass, thimble for the stove pipe and zinc to go under the stove, which you state are required.

Kindly forward vouchers, in duplicate, properly certified, for the expenditure incurred in connection with this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

N. P. Freeman, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

After writing you with regard to the house at the Seacote Grand, Lunenburg Co., now vacant but formerly used as the teacher's residence when the school on the Grand was open.

James Hammond, an old Indian with no permanent residence wishes to have the use of this house during the winter months. His daughter is willing to help house for him if they can get permission to use this house.

I told him that there were no funds available if the house required any repairs and he is willing to take it as it is.

Please inform me at your earliest convenience if this request meets with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
J. Stanley Christie
Agent for Lunenburg Co.
Oct. 18.
Ottawa, October 28, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, in which you recommend that the teacher's residence in connection with the New Germany Indian Day School on the Scarsdale Grant, Lunenburg Co., be granted for the use of James Hammond during the coming winter months.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will consent to James Hammond occupying this building until next spring. We are not, however, prepared to provide the cost of any repairs or any other expense in fitting up the building. You may inform James Hammond of the approval granted for him to occupy the teacher's residence during the coming winter.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. S. Chisholm, M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Shane Bay, N.S.

3rd Oct. 1894

Shuster Reed Esq.
Dept. Ind. Bldg. Ind. Affairs
Sir,

I have the honor to report that in cooperation with the school inspectors I have engaged Miss Bella Johnson to teach the improving Indian School. Miss Johnson has passed successfully the examination that will entitle her to a 3-year certificate after she has attended a term at a model school. Meanwhile, the school inspectors will give her a permit to teach.

I have also engaged Mr. David Chadwick, an Indian of Cape Croker, to teach the Henry Huber School. Mr. Chadwick has taught the Indian School at Cape Croker for upwards of ten years and brings a satisfactory testimonial from his inspectors and agent.

Miss M.C. Morrison has resumed her duties at the Shabangaga Indian School.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient servant,
Thos. Hallett
Indian Agent

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS,
OTTAWA, ONT.

SIR,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your favor of the 25th inst., enclosing copy of a communication received from 7th Chief Moses Beaucage of the Nepising Band complaining that Miss Helen Quinn, the teacher of the Nepising Indian School was not giving entire satisfaction in her conduct of the school & also complaining that he had written to me about the matter but had received no reply.

In reply I wish to say that the only information I have received in regard to this matter was when I visited the Reserve in October last when 7th Chief Moses Beaucage complained that Miss Quinn was usually an hour late in opening the school on Monday mornings owing to her going home to North Bay on Friday evenings & not returning to the Reserve until the first train on Monday mornings which is due at Beaucage about 9 o'clock a.m. I promptly called Miss Quinn's attention to the complaint & intimated that she must attend to her duties according to instructions. I have presumed that she has been doing so. As it is evident that she has not been doing so I shall write her at once stating that she must attend to her duties more promptly.

Moses Beaucage's statement that he had written to me about the matter but had received no reply is not correct, as I have not received any letter from him at all on this subject.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Maclean
Indian Agent

OTTAWA, 30th March, 1901.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that the Department has been advised that Miss Quinn, teacher of the lipissing school at Beausage, is not attending properly to her duties. As this is the second complaint of this kind that has reached the Department, I would like you to notify Miss Quinn that her services will have to be dispensed with if any further complaints are made.

It has also been reported that she refuses to teach the children of Mr. Molamara, the station master at Beausage, who has been paying the usual fee for their tuition. Please inform Miss Quinn that it is the wish of the Department that these children should receive instruction at the school.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary
Sir,

In reply to your favor of the 30th ultimo which is in reference to a complaint made to you that Miss Quinn, teacher of the Nepissing Indian School at Bancroft has not been attending properly to her duties, I wish to say that I shall inform Miss Quinn of the complaint made, request her to see that in future she so conducts herself as not to give any further cause for complaint, or I shall be compelled to request her to hand in her resignation.

Your letter does not state the nature of the complaint lodged against Miss Quinn, and I shall be glad if you will kindly advise me what the complaint consists of, so that I can, on my next visit to the Reserve (which will be I presume sometime towards the end of the present month), investigate the cause of complaint.

I may say that both Mr. School Inspector Grant & myself look upon Miss Quinn as a capable teacher, judging by an examination of the pupils under her charge which I made last fall the progress they are making is very satisfactory.

In regard to the complaint that she refuses to teach the children of Mr. McNamara, the station...
Sir,

I think this statement is hardly correct. Mr. McNamara's children being of white origin progress more rapidly in their studies than the Indian children, & Mr. McNamara desires that special classes should be established for the advancement of his children which would of course entail considerable extra work on the teacher. I shall however investigate this matter also on my next visit to the Reserve & find out the exact position of affairs & report to you more fully meantime.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant

W.B. Maclean
Indian Dept.
OTTAWA, 13th April, 1901.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant with reference to the complaints made against Miss Quinn, teacher of the Nipissing school; and in reply I beg to say that no specific charges were made, the complaint being a verbal one of general neglect of duty.

Although it is the wish of the Department that the children of Mr McNamara, the station master, should receive instruction at the school, it does not desire that special classes shall be formed for their benefit to the detriment of the work of the other pupils.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean

F.B. Maclean, Esq.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that Miss Sweezy has assumed charge of the Reserve Indian School at Beauce without having received any appointment or any authority from me to do so.

The first intimation I had of this was on receipt of a letter from her on the 30th ultimo asking for some school supplies for the school, the letter being signed "Sarah Sweezy Teacher". Prior to the receipt of this letter I had appointed Miss Christina McLeod of Pembroke as teacher of the school & authorized her to proceed to Beauce to open the school at the earliest possible moment which she did on Sept 1st. On her arrival at Beauce she found the school in charge of Miss Sweezy consequently she returned to Pembroke.

On receipt of Miss Sweezy's letter I at once wrote her that I was at a loss to know by what authority she was teaching at Beauce as she had received no appointment to do so. I also informed her that Miss McLeod had been appointed to take charge of the school & would arrive at Beauce on the 1st inst when I would expect her to vacate the school premises at once.

As Miss McLeod was engaged by me in good faith to take charge of this school I have written her that she may consider herself in the employ of the Department of Indian Affairs and

That all expenses incurred in going to Beauce or returning to her home at Humboldt will be paid by your Department. I have also notified her to hold herself in readiness to again proceed to Beauce as soon as Miss Sweney has been compelled to vacate the school.

I have today written Chief James Commanda of the Nepisigong Band expressing my astonishment at the state of affairs which exist at the Beauce school, notifying him that Miss Sweney must leave the school at once & informing him that Miss McLeod the duly authorized teacher for this school would hold herself in readiness to proceed to Beauce as soon as Miss Sweney had vacated the premises.

Dear Sir,

I write to find out if it is possible to have a school for Indian children at Wolf Lake, as I find that there has been a school started for the Kippewa Indians at Hunter's Point. This school has never been used by the Indians as the Indians never go there and consequently get no
Benefit from it. Now there is a lady at Wolf Lake, Miss Kate Dobbin who has been teaching some of the Indian children at Wolf Lake and is residing there. She has no diploma as she never had the need of it but educated at Jean Marie College of Quebec and the lady in charge of the Institution told her that if ever she needed a position as governess that to apply to her and she would certify to her capability to teach. The difficulty up here seems to be that teachers do not care to stop up here long if the department should send us a favorable answer we would go to work to build a school house. Miss Mary Dobbin gives the name of Mother St. Angela Convent of Jean Marie Illery Rue to whom you could refer waiting an answer.

Ottawa, March 11th, 1910.

Rev. Sir,

Joseph Petrimont, Chief of the Kippewa Indians, has applied to the Department for the establishment of a day school at Wolf Lake. He states that Wolf Lake would be a better point for a school than Hunters Point, as the Indians do not go to the latter place. The return from the Hunters Point school, which has been in operation for some four years, shows that the attendance has gradually lessened, the average last year being only seven.

The Department will be glad to have any information you can give as to the number of children of school age, the character and habits of the Indians and whether they are permanently located, as well as any other details that will enable it to come to a decision in regard to the Chief's request.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 380578, relative to the request of Miss Doeker for the summer school, I beg to make the following remarks:

1. With regard to Wolf Lake I have little confidence as to the success at present, as the families that have children to send to school, and that are half-breeds and Indians, do not reside in the locality of the school, and, besides, I should fear very much that the inconvenience of the travelling and the distance and the lack of comfort would frighten a person not used to the life of the woods.

2. As for the school at Longue Pointe the difficulty is not so great in the matter of distance; but I beg to remark that the school—or rather the church, which is used as a school-house—and near which the Indians camp during the summer—is altogether alone at the present time, there are no white people at all in the neighbourhood. The school mistress will conduct her kitchen as Mrs. McLaren did last summer and as the one at Abitibi also does.

The school at Bear Island is differently situated; it is easy to board there. Besides the great majority of the children of Bear Island, Timagami, speak English, while it is still rare to hear the Indians of those other places speak English.
None the less, I shall be glad to accept your assistance for these different localities by your sending school mistresses.

Very respectfully,

Sir,

In reply to No.360378-1 of April 29, 1918, I have to inform you that I was aware last summer and the preceding of complaints on the part of Indians of Wolf Lake, who claimed that their children were making almost no progress, that they did not understand English, and that they wished to have a competent teacher understanding both languages, English and Algonkin, come there. Miss A. Robinson is certainly not able to understand and translate Algonkin, and consequently to advance the Indian children as easily and rapidly as a teacher who spoke both languages. The Catholic Indians have also asked me what their children can receive in the way of religious instruction in their own language while they continue incapable of understanding English. I know Miss Maria King, and have known her for fifteen years. I believe that if it would be agreeable to the Department to make a change, this person is well qualified to fill the position. She is educated and speaks both languages well, and lives in the vicinity of Wolf Lake. I believe, moreover, that she would be esteemed by the Indians. Her address, if it be required, is as follows.

Sir,

Referring to your letter No. 560378 of the 30th of August, 1912, I beg to say that the situation in regard to the establishment of a summer school at Wolf Lake for the Indians is much improved. Up to the present time the Indians of those parts did not agree as to the place where the school ought to be held. Last summer I succeeded in convincing them that we ought to build a new church (the old one falling into ruins at Grass Lake, ten miles farther than the new site selected). This new site is exactly at Wolf Lake; and all the Indians have agreed to have the school taught in this new church, around which they will reside during the summer months. Nevertheless, I believe that the time has come when it would be well that your agent should himself give an account of the situation, or the number, and of the views of these Indians. The best time for that would be the month of May, at the end of the month, or the month of June or July. I could inform them of the date of the visit of your agent so that all might assemble at the time of that visit. These Indians are also in a precarious condition of health; scrofula and tuberculosis are beginning to make ravages, and I believe that the visit of the physician for some days would be a great assistance to them.

If all goes well with my affairs, I intend to build my new church in spring. If your Department agrees to give a school to these Indians, who certainly are
anxious to improve themselves, I shall be glad to supply the building and the desks on the same conditions as for Abitibi, that is to say, $5.00 rent a month. If your Department opens the school in the beginning of June, and if my building is not ready, Mr. Ed. Robinson can furnish one in the meantime; in that case it would be necessary to see that the material should be sent in time.

Very humbly

Your servant,

Is. Evans, O.M.I.
Missionary

P.S. I believe also that Miss Agnes Robinson, over thirty years of age, having taken a course in the United States, is in a position to teach this school.

À M. le Ministre du Département Indien,
Parlement d'Ottawa, Canada,

Honorable Monsieur,

Nous avons dans la localité de
Niagara Station une ou six familles indiennes et
cette ou cinq familles qui demeurent ici une grande
partie de l'année. Toutes ces familles possèdent
encore une cinquantaine d'enfants dont
il est moins certain qu'ils allaient à l'école.

Il existe une hospitalière de terrain, elle
ne ferme pas le cœur au municipalité publique
provinciale. C'est pourquoi nous implorons
l'aide du gouvernement fédéral.

La plupart de ces enfants sont métis, c'est pour
un certain temps nous demandons au département
Indien de l'accepter de nous.

Une école indienne au Wolf River et à Butte
nous ont obtenu de notre État seulement un subside
de $400. Une éducation plus d'élèves que nous
espérons que la même faveur nous sera accordée.

Si vous donnez quelques renseignements sur
information, le R.P. André Payet, M.M. Mathieu.
pour le fournir. Peut-être que nous une
de plus de famille pourrait aider un peu,
mais leurs familles sont très nombreuses et ils
sont bien pauvres.

Voici encore deux maîtres qui nous ont
fait une visite, une à 85 ans mais elle est
à 80 en apparence, la personne qui écrit ici est

C'est donc une horrible affaire, je suis

Kipawa Station, April 14, 1912

The Minister of the Indian Department,
Parliament of Ottawa,
Canada.

Hon. Sir,

We have in the locality of Kipawa Station five or six resident families and four or five families that reside here a great part of the year. All these families have together some fifty children, twenty-eight of whom at least are of an age to attend school. These people, not being land-owners, cannot take advantage of the provincial school municipality. That is why we beg you to give us Dominion Government assistance.

Most of these children are half-breeds. It is for them especially that we ask the Indian Department to pay attention to us.

An Indian school at Wolf Lake and others have obtained from your Department a grant of $400. We have more pupils than they have, and we hope that the same favour will be granted us.

If you desire to have any particulars or information, the Rev. Father Andre Paquet, O.M.I., Mattawa, will furnish you with the same.

Perhaps some of the heads of families would be able to assist a little; but their families are very numerous and they are very poor.

Two school mistresses have offered us their services,—one for $25.00 a month and the other for $30.00. On adding the board, which costs at least $15 here, we shall be obliged to spend at least $40.00, without counting heating and maintenance.
As I am the one that is building the school,
I trust that the Department will assist me. Negotiations
can be carried on with me or with the Rev. Father Paquet
if you so prefer.

Counting on a prompt reply,

I am

Yours faithfully,

Gilbert Samuel
Ottawa, April 25, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant requesting a grant from this Department for the establishment of a school at Kipawa Station.

In reply I beg to say that this Department has no responsibility for the education of half-breed children and cannot, therefore, give your request consideration. The school at Wolfe Lake, to which you refer, is a temporary summer school for the education of Indian children during the short period in which they are located at that point. As the families on whose behalf you make this application are not Indians the Department cannot see why they are not entitled to the privileges extended to the other residents of the municipality in so far as providing for the education of their children is concerned.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Mr. Gilbert Samuel,
Kipawa Station, Que.

Sir,

Dear Sir,

You are doubtless aware that Revillon Bros. have for years established a trading post on the mainland about six miles distant from Moore Fort. They have succeeded in charming away nearly 60 per cent of the Indians from Moore Fort so that we feel the necessity of building a church and opening a day school at that place which is called by Revillon Bros. "Moose River Post" but which we have named "French Post" to avoid any confusion with Moore Fort. We have secured a site and are removing the old school building at Moore Fort over there, which with some new material will make a good school church combined. I write now to notify you that we are prepared to begin the school work in April 1st, and that when in due course you decide...
We readily witness for this new day school, we will expect a fulfillment of the standing promise or understanding in the way of the usual Government allowances for each schools. There are fully 20 children of school age at that station all the year round, and in summer 35.

Yours sincerely,

John S. Anderson
Bishop of Moose Cree

Dear Sir:

Yours of the 6th Nov,

No.378718-1 to hand re the question of the Moose River School.

The chief objections to taking the children from this day school into the Boarding School are first of all, that we have had so much trouble with local children in the past owing to the parents being so near that we do not encourage those with parents to enter. Then again, of late years we have had no trouble to fill the school with children either fatherless, motherless or orphans, mostly from distant homes. I have just received a letter from our Missionary at Rupert's House saying that there are a number of very poor families there and asking if it would be possible to get some of them into the Boarding School. I was obliged to reply that we were full up. We should much prefer that the School in question be allowed for the present to go on as it is, until an increase or decrease decides the matter.

ENGLISH RIVER.

EX'D.

Some of the Indians enquired if there was a new school to be built at Pagwa.

George Patrick.
My dear Doc:

How are the flies doing on the Bay? They have sort of died out up here, at present.

I have received notice from the Dept. of Education for the province of Ontario, that they will give me a grant for teaching the non-treaty children at Pagwa, so we are going to open a school there for the winter months. There are some Treaty children there too, the Wesley families Sutherlands etc., will the Dept. give me a grant for teaching these children? I know that they would not be cut to the Sioux-Lockout School anyway, and also that this would not encourage the English River people to the line.

I also feel that they children taught in such a school, would not be cut off from their own life so much as they are at a place like Sioux-Lockout or Chapleau.

Did Bill Beal from Pitts. arrive I hope he had a fine visit. I was up to Ogoki, a couple of weeks ago. It took me two days to go up the big river. I had a swell trip. Phyllis & Allan Black wished to be remembered to you, if I was writing at any time.

Well cheese for now. I hope that you will be able to help me with the school, as I want to do all I can for these people.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Saint Mary's Mission
English River
Via Pagwa River
N. Ontario

Aug.6,1937
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

Please find enclosed a letter the Rev. N. Clarke who is stationed at English River during the summer and it seems is moving to Pagwa River for the winter.

I am not at all sure that opening a school for Indians at Pagwa would not encourage the Indians at English River to go to the line. I left instructions with the Post Master at Pagwa that he was not to give any relief to English River Indians except the ones that make their home there; a list of these Indians was left with him so that there might not be the same danger of the Indians going there when they know that they will not receive any help from the Dept.

I pass the letter on to you without any recommendation.

Yours truly,

W.L. Tyre

Dept. of Indian Affairs

Re:- Indian Children at Pagwa School.

Ernest Wesley

Alfred Wesley:- These boys are resident at Pagwa. Ernest was at Residential School, but since the Civil Aviation has commenced work at Pagwa River. Their father is able to get part time work, and their Mother, is able to take in washing, which keeps them off the Dept. relief account, at least so far this winter. If these boys were not at home then, Fred (their father) would have to spend half his time getting wood. Don't you think we are doing right teaching these people to be independent? If Fred went trapping instead of hauling wood, with the boys away, then Minnie (their Mother) would have to do it, and she wouldn't be able to take in the washing etc., thus cutting down their income considerably.

Elsie Wesley

Elsie's mother died last spring on the way home from hospital. Elsie has to look after, one child, and one mental deficient, she is able to attend on an average of 3 hours a day. Should she be denied an education? Other schooling would be impossible for her.

Gilbert Fairies
Thomas Fairies
Both are orphans, sons of John Jr., & Willie Fairies. These boys are small, but not too small that they can't help their grandfather, who is looking after them to trap rabbits, and help with the wood. They rightly belong to English River, but as their father can talk English well, he works when he can for the Dept. Civil Aviation. Thus trying with trapping he is trying to keep himself and the children.

Gdo. Spence

Joe Spence: These boys are Romans and you may think it strange that they attend our school. But no child is turned away. As they all have a right to a liberal education. These children would not be sent out to school.

Evelyn Sagana quib Evelyn is the only companion her widowed mother has.

These are the most outstanding cases, which I present to you. But what I want to point out, that as my letter week to you showed, that these children have got to have some training at home. Not that I am trying to belittle the Residential School system, but the boy (Simeon Taylor) whom I wrote you about, was a Residential school boy, and I find that when they return home they have learnt to smoke long before they should.

The rare prospects of Pagwa opening up, the air-port is close, a road branching off to Long-Lac is supposed to be going through shortly, the only way to keep these people self-reliant, is to have someone on the spot.

The Residential School never takes half of the children here, and until this year, no great fuss was made about them. There will always be a number of children here whom the residential will never take, owing
different circumstances, which we can reach, with a winter school.

Too, there is no use trying to bluff ourselves, that last week was the first case of liquor trouble. Well the only way to stop it is to have someone right at the place.

I feel that you will have to agree that, after reading this, we here are endeavouring as much as possible to follow out your own idea; which was published in the papers last summer, to make these people as much as possible self-supporting.

It is as great an interest to make these children good citizens, to us, as it is the wish of the Dent.

We have carried on this work for one quarter now, and there have been costs which we have had to meet, which are justifiable and are not out of the ordinary sphere of things, such as building desks, getting a stove, wood, and school supplies. But we did not feel justified in presenting our case until we had done some work, and you could judge for yourself, our sincerity. The children are attending school, little things are being accomplished; as I don't claim we are able to turn the world over in a day, and with this, these children are fulfilling their duties at home.

These children are not only taught the regular school lessons, but also sanitation and hygiene. The girls receive instruction in sewing, knitting, etc., from Mrs. Clark, while the boys are taught the use of the hammer and saw.

I fully realize that the Dent is budgetted right to the hilt, and that any additional expenses, are almost impossible to be worked in, but there are other years, and this is only the start.
But I feel quite justified in asking the Dept. for assistance, as I am sure we are giving back through these people, every dollar that is spent on them.

I am including a list of requirements, which you may think out of the question, or may not, but I would very much appreciate some assistance this year if it only means sending the school equipment, or part of it.

Hoping that I have not been too verbose in my explanations, and that you will be able to understand our position here. I know you have of the uselessness of a school, here. But I wished to produce some evidence in the way of results before putting this question to you, as it is easy to type letters, but another thing to back up one's statements, with some sort of results.

Thanking you for your kind attention in this matter, and hoping that you are keeping in the best of health. I remain;

Yours sincerely

Neville R. Clarke L.Th.(Rev.)

Supt. of College & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dea Mr. Hoey;

Many thanks for yours of the 12th inst. I understand the situation perfectly, and appreciate your help and sympathy.

There is another matter which I feel should be attended to now as it is near spring. The Dept. of Civil Aviation will soon be commencing work at the Beacon site, and I hold. For this job they need many labourers. The type of work done is chiefly brushing, clearing stumps, and digging ditches.

Last summer some of the Indians here were able to obtain work, but much of it was done by Provincial unemployed.

This winter as far as I've been able to judge has not been very successful as regards the fur hunt. And it would be a very fine thing for these people if they were able to work instead of going on relief.

From what I have seen before I feel that the Indian would be superior to the white man for this type of work, in this section, because they are not affected so much by the flies.

If you could take the matter up with the Hon. Mr. Howe of the Dept. of Transport, I will do everything in my power to see that they get enough men.

This would not only affect the Indians here, but would also give employment to the Indians at English River, as it is only 70 miles between the two places, and many of them come up to Pagwa during the summer.

Thanking you again for your support in the matter of the school, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Neville R. Clarke, L.Th.

Mr. Hoey

Re: Indian Children at Pagwa School.

Ernest Wesley

Alfred Wesley: These boys are resident at Pagwa. Ernest was at Residential School, but since the Civil Aviation has commenced work at Pagwa River. Their father is able to get part-time work, and their mother is able to take in washing, which keeps them off the Dept. relief account, at least so far this winter. If these boys were sent at once then Fred (their father) would have to spend half his time getting wood. Don't you think we are doing right teaching these people to be independent? If Fred went trapping instead of gathering wood, with the boy away, then Minnie (their mother) would have to do it, and she wouldn't be able to take in the washing etc., thus cutting down their income considerably.

Elate Wesley: Elate's mother died last spring on the way home from hospital. Elate has to look after one child and one mental deficient, she is able to attend on an average of 3 hours a day. Should she be denied an education? Other schooling would be impossible for her.

Gilbert Fairies

Thomas Fairies: Both are orphans, sons of John Jr. & Willie Fairies. These boys are small, but not too small that they can't help their grandfather who is looking after them to trap rabbits, and help with the wood. They rightly belong to English River, but as their father can talk English well he works when he can for the Dept. Civil Aviation. Thus trying with trapping he is trying to keep himself and the children.

Geo. Spence

Joe Spence: These boys are Romans and you may think it strange that they attend our school but no child is turned away as they all have a right to a liberal education. These children would not be sent out to school.

Evelyn Saranacib: Evelyn is the only companion her widowed mother has.
These are the most outstanding cases which I present to you. But what I want to point out that as my letter week to you showed that these children have got to have some training at home. Not that I am trying to belittle the Residential School system but the boy (Simeon Taylor) whom I wrote you about was a Residential School boy and I find that when they return home they have learnt to smoke long before they should.

There are prospects of Paswa opening up the air-port is close, a road branching off to Long Lac is supposed to be going through shortly. The only way to keep these people self-reliant, is to have someone on the spot.

The Residential School never takes half of the children here and until this year no great fuss was made about them. There will always be a number of children here whom the residential will never take, owing to different circumstances which we can reach with a winter school.

Too there is no use trying to bluff ourselves, that last week was the first case of liquor trouble. Well the only way to stop it is to have someone right at the place.

I feel that you will have to agree that, after reading this, we here are endeavouring as much as possible to follow out your own idea which was published in the papers last summer, to make these people as much as possible self-supporting.

It is as great an interest to make these children good citizens to us as it is the wish of the Department.

We have carried on this work for one quarter now, and there have been costs which we have had to meet, which are justifiable and are not out of the ordinary sphere of things, such as building desks, getting a stove, wood, and school supplies. But we did not feel justified in presenting our case until we had done some work and you could judge for yourself our sincerity. The children are attending school. Little things are being accomplished; as I don't claim we are able to turn the world over in a day, and with this, these children are fulfilling their duties at home.

These children are not only taught the regular school lessons, but also sanitation and hygiene, every morning they are washed thoroughly. The girls receive instruction in sewing, knitting, etc., from Mrs. Clarke while the boys are taught the use of the hammer and saw.
I fully realize that the Department is budgeted right to the hilt, and that any additional expenses are almost impossible to be worked in, but there are other years, and this is only the start, but I feel quite justified in asking the Department for assistance, as I am sure we are giving back through these people, every dollar that is spent on them.

I am including a list of requirements which you may think out of the question, or may not, but I would very much appreciate some assistance, this year if it only means sending the school equipment or part of it.

Hoping that I have not been too verbose in my explanations, and that you will be able to understand our position here. I know you have heard of the uselessness of a school here, but I wishes to produce some evidence in the way of results before putting this question to you, as it is easy to type letters, but another thing to back up one's statements with some sort of results.

Thanking you for your kind attention in this matter, and hoping that you are keeping in the best of health, I remain,

Yours sincerely,
(Rev.)
(Sgd.) Neville R. Clarke, L.Th.
Papwa River, Ontario.

Re: Road to Pagwa River

Dear Sir:

At present there is a survey party inland south of Pagwa River, looking over the belt of Greenstones which runs from Klotz lake north east. The reason for this is that the Trans-Canada Highway will have a branch which will run from Nippigon to Hearst via Klotz Lake, and possibly Pagwa River.

This road will likely run south of Pagwa River just far enough to make it inaccessible by automobile, if this road was road was brought to Pagwa River then run east, or a short branch run off the main road for 5 or 6 miles, it would open up a great tourist possibility for this section, as we have a continuous run of good water from here to James' Bay a matter of 350 miles. This would be a great boon to the Indians here and at English River, and would also help the Indians at Albany as tourists making this trip would pick up an additional guide to travel across salt water to Moose Factory.

The sale of the local handicraft would be increased too, which would be great help. It would not be at all difficult to see that the Indian received direct benefit from such a venture.

I have had letters from several parties wishing to make this trip, and have not done so because of the poor train service, and not being able to use their automobiles.

There is a possibility that the road will run right into Pagwa River, but if this was assured, I feel that the effect would be well repaid, as it would give this Indians in this section some permanent summer employment and would go a long way to making them self-supporting.

Hoping that the matter may receive due consideration, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

My Dear Mr. Hoey:

It is now a month since the letter, which you wrote informing me about the grant for the school. In the meantime I have had a letter from Dr. Tyre, saying that he had tried his best to get a grant but was unsuccessful.

I feel that you have been grossly unfair to us at Pagwa River. I cannot help but notice the difference in promptness with which these letters are answered and those, which had to do with getting work for the Indians and keeping them off relief.

I have gone to considerable expense, in good faith, and by the instructions of Dr. Tyre at last treaty time, in painting the school and making suggested alterations. Also building a church so we would not have services in the school house, so that there would be no chance of any infect from any source this also on the Doctor's suggestion.

Now you wish to close the matter, without informing me, or even answering, the letter's forwarded to you regarding this.

How much do you think has been saved the Dept. by my keeping the Indians employed at the Dept. Civil Aviation? Up until two months past. No one else kept them on, I am sure, if they had been left to their own resources. The Dept. would be paying them rations, and they would have had nothing to go trapping with. Whereas for the last year there has only be three parties receiving help, two old men, one almost blind, and a widow.
But we are not here to consider just a Dollar and cent value of the Indian, or are we? And not to try and help them.

I fully realize in the light of recent events that finances can be and may have been tightened up, to the breaking point, but that does not excuse not answering any letters or giving a sympathetic ear to any plea.

I am greatly in need of text books, writing equipment, and blackboard, this would entail opening no new account, or grant, and I hope that you will be able to do something for us. It certainly makes a difficult task more difficult, if one feels that the Dept. has no interest in the task of lifting the people to a little higher level.

Dear Mr. Clarke:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 21st instant, in which you express regret at the failure of the Department to recognize your claims for assistance in the operation of the school at Pagwa River.

It is difficult for me to convince myself that a Civil Servant can be unfair at any time in his treatment of the teachers in charge of our schools, particularly the pioneer missionaries in the outlying sections of the Dominion. There seems to be a very widespread tendency on the part of human beings to look for the worst and it is too much perhaps to expect teachers or even clergymen to escape this tendency.

Regulations governing the operation of Indian day schools were prepared and published by the Department a few months ago. I am sending forward to you a copy of these regulations for your information. You will note that, in paragraph 7, Indian day school teachers are requested to petition for supplies through the Indian agent. We have learned from experience that correspondence with Indian day school teachers and with Indian agents on matters relating to the operation of schools has led to endless dissatisfaction and confusion - hence the new regulation.

In my letter to you dated September 21, 1938, I stated: "My understanding is that we communicated with you a few days ago with respect to this matter. It is altogether likely that the letter has reached you by this time". The officials inform me that the letter referred to in this communication was a letter sent forward to Dr. Tyrer, Indian Agent, dated September 2, 1938.

The actual facts are that before a grant can be made -

Rev. Neville R. Clarke, L. Th.,
St. Clement's Mission,
Pagwa River, Ontario.
be made for the instruction of Indian children in Indian day or residential schools, such schools must be established by Order-in-Council. What is perhaps more important still is that provision for such grants must be made in the current year's estimates. Your school was not established by Order-in-Council, no provision was made in the estimates for a grant and, consequently, no grant was paid. The Indian agent was notified to this effect in departmental letters dated September 2 and October 5, 1938.

The agent himself took the position, in a letter dated March 2, 1938, that only a small number of Indian children should receive instruction at the Pagwa River School. He intimated in that communication that a few years ago a lot of Indians were sent away from Pagwa by the Department and that it would be very unfortunate indeed if any encouragement were given them to return. His request that the Department make provision for the education of children that had lived at Pagwa River for a number of years was considered after the receipt of the agent's letter by the officials. The estimates, however, for the year 1938-39 had been prepared at that time and had been sent forward for consideration by Parliament.

It is our intention to make provision for a grant to the Pagwa River School in the estimates now under consideration.

I can understand the inconvenience you have experienced when you remodelled and reconstructed your school, in the hope that a departmental grant would be received. Nevertheless, I feel confident you will readily appreciate the position in which the officials here found themselves. It was simply impossible for us to make a grant, when no provision was made in the estimates for the regular establishment of this school.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Reverend Sir:

I desire to refer to the last paragraph of your letter of the 14th ultimo, in connection with the school at Pagua River.

From previous correspondence I understand that this school is attended by both Indians and white children. It therefore comes under the class known as combined Indian and white schools. It is not our practice to pay any regular annual fee to the teacher of a school in this class. Besides, we are not permitted to provide the salary of a teacher of a day school which is not located on an Indian reserve.

I have given very careful consideration to the question of what financial assistance we can give, and I feel that the best we can do is to allow an amount of $20.00 a year, based on the average attendance, for each Indian child that attends the Pagua River Combined School. You may, therefore, prepare a return, on the regular day school return form, showing the Indian children who were in attendance for that period. All information required by the form should be given and it should then be forwarded to Indian Agent Dr. Tyner, who will certify it, if correct, and forward here for payment of the grant promised in this letter.

I may add that the allowance we are making to you is considerably larger than at other similar schools, and this increased grant is being provided in order to assist you as far as possible.

Dear borne;

Dear Mr. Melinnes:

Last spring I received notice that the school grant at St. Clement's would be cut. I took this up immediately with the late Dr. Tyrer. He told me to open the beginning of Oct. and submit the returns to him. He pointed out that, in order to justify our existence I should endeavour to continue to keep as many families as possible off the relief rolls.

Since last spring there has in this area been one ration, value $2.50 issued to an able-bodied Indian, and that was to help the widows dig up their potatoes. This has been done by finding employment, when possible, and by pushing native handicrafts.

I feel that it only fair to expect the grant, for without it, we will have to curtail our work, which only means reverting to the old system of relief. In these times I don't think anyone should expect to receive remunerations for every little thing that is done, but in the case of the school, where there are expenses in maintaining it, I feel they we should be taken care of.
There is no need of taking up your time with lengthy arguments, but if you consult the relief accounts for here and compare them with other points I think you will agree with me.

Yours sincerely,

Reverend Sir:

I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant with reference to the school which you are conducting at Pagwa River.

It is extremely difficult, due to present regulations, to make a grant for this school. It is contrary to our policy at the present time to provide relief, education or medical services for Indians who are residing off their reserve.

It is our intention to have conditions at Pagwa River fully investigated in the near future but in the meantime it has been decided that an amount of $25.00 a month will be allowed toward your salary as teacher of this school for the period October 1, 1940, to June 30, 1941. In making this payment it should be distinctly understood that this Branch does not obligate itself to continue payments to this school after the end of the current academic year. However, as stated above, it is hoped by that time to obtain a report regarding conditions and our future policy in regard to the school will then be decided.

Deputy Minister of Education,
Parliament Buildings,
Toronto:

Sir:

During the course of a recent visit to a newly formed Public School at Pagwa River (75 miles west of Hearst) my attention was drawn to the situation there with respect to Indian children. I realize that the education of these people is a matter for the Federal Government, but feel that the facts might be laid before you for any action you may deem proper.

Pagwa River is a small settlement which, including the airport two miles west, probably has a population of 20 white people in all. In addition there are several families of half-whites and an estimated 300-400 Indians. Instructions from the Ontario Department of Education permit the admission of non-treaty Indians only to the Public School, and in consequence an estimated 60-80 Indian children are receiving no education whatsoever.

I was informed by the Indian Agent for the district some time ago, that it is desired that all Indians move to Calstock Reserve, some 55 miles east of Pagwa, where better facilities are available. From a visit to Pagwa, however, it would be my opinion that the Indians would be most reluctant to move away unless extreme pressure were brought upon them. The Pagwa River, which runs within 300 yards of a Hudson's Bay trading post, appears to have ample open water free from rapids; while the Kabinakagami River, running near Calstock would entail much portaging.

As a result of this situation many requests for admission of treaty Indian children to the Public School at Pagwa River must be refused, and the School Board itself feels that some action might be taken for the benefit of the Indians of the locality.

Yours respectfully,

(sgd.) G. L. Woodruff

In reply to your letter as above, regarding the school situation at Pagwa River.

The Inspector of Public Schools is quite right in saying that there are a large number of Indian children at Pagwa River who are not attending school, nor have they ever attended school, for any length of time.

This was the main reason for the establishment of the Constance Lake Reserve, but as we did not have any suitable accommodation for the families at Constance Lake no pressure has been placed on them to move, some have of their own accord, and when our housing project is completed this year I think that a number will then move to Calstock.

There are only two white people at Pagwa River itself, the remainder being at the airport, and these two white people are the ones who are creating opposition to the Indians moving from Pagwa River to Constance Lake, they are both traders, one the manager of the Hudson's Bay Co., and the other a Mr. Ericsson, if these Indians move they both lose out in their respective businesses.

The white people are not worried about the Indian children getting an education, the Indian school did function spasmodically some time ago, and at that time they would not let their children go with the Indian children to school, but now that there is a chance of the Indians moving away they are very keen to have them stay.
This situation is not new, but has been going on for years, and now that we are about ready to have them move the opposition is becoming more pronounced.

I can appreciate Mr. Woodruff's letter as he is definitely interested in the education of all the children of his inspectorate, but I also know the Pagwa situation much better than he does, also the background.

The matter of the Pagwa River being more easily navigated than the Kabina Kagami really does not enter into question with any seriousness, all these people are moving between Pagwa River and Constance Lake a dozen times a year, and they could live at Constance Lake and go to Pagwa to use the river for travelling without any inconvenience to themselves, it is nothing more than they are doing all summer.

At Constance Lake there is work for them, they do nothing all summer at Pagwa except make a trip for the Hudson's Bay Co., portaging supplies to some of their down river posts, at Constance Lake they are within twenty miles of a Doctor and hospital, whereas at Pagwa they never see a doctor, also they will be more closely supervised with better houses and all round living conditions.

I would wish to maintain the close cooperation that has existed in my agency with the Ontario Provincial Inspector, I have always found them to truly interested in the education of Indian children as well as whites, but feel that in this case it would be just another obstacle to overcome by allowing them to attend the Public school at Pagwa River, which incidentally has been closed for a considerable part of the academic year.

Dear Sir,—

We have been asked by the officials of Heatherton School Section No 25, to petition the Department of Indian Affairs for a grant of $1000.00 to be used in the construction of a new school. At first this would seem like an unreasonable request but after studying the matter, we feel that you will appreciate with us the justice of the claim.

The facts of the case are as follows:—

In Heatherton Section there are two Indian Reservations — one at Sumnerside and another approximately five miles west from the present school site. In these Reservations there are twelve Indian children of school age and this number is practically one-sixth of the total number of pupils in the section. We have permitted these children to attend our school, causing congested class room conditions, with the result that the Provincial Inspector of Schools has asked for the enlargement of the old school or the building of a new one. At a regular meeting of the ratepayers on Oct. 15th, 1926, it was decided to build a new, two-department school and $4500.00 was accordingly voted for the purpose — this amount to be supplemented by funds from other sources as it was felt that the total cost of the building would be in the vicinity of $6000.00. On the attendance basis of Indian children we feel that your Department would be justified in contributing one-sixth of this amount, or, as was stated above, $1000.00.

Again, it is the desire of the Inspector to establish an efficient, consolidated High School Department in the Heatherton school. This is in line with our wishes as well as the aims of the Department of Education. In the event of this plan materializing the adjoining sections will contribute to the general support of the school in addition to paying tuition fees per pupil. This High School Department would be open to pupils from not only the Heatherton and Sumnerside Reservations, but the Afton District as well. At the present time a High School pupil, M. L. Prosper, from the Afton Reservation, is being educated in one of the Antigonish schools at a cost of $180.00 to the Department. This cost would be greatly reduced were it convenient for Mr. Prosper to attend an up-to-date school near his home. It will be possible for him or others to do this when our new school, with an improved High School Department, is in operation, provided financial assistance is available from Dominion funds.

Although an Indian school is maintained at Afton it will never be of service, on account of distance, to the children in the Heatherton and Sumnerside Reservations. Hence, it may be that in the near future your Department will be confronted with the question of providing a separate school for these children. From the standpoint of economy we feel that the paying of a building grant to our school, which would entitle Indian children the privilege of attending, would be favourably received by you.

No doubt, as a further provision to the paying of this grant, you will require the plans and specifications of the new building to be approved by the Department of Education and in this regard we wish to state that this provision will receive our endorseration.

It is hoped that our building program will be well under way before the end of the school year and hence we respectfully ask your early attention to this matter. Again, we earnestly trust that after your careful consideration your reply will be a favourable one.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

After studying the contents of the attached letter I wish to confirm the appeal for a subvention from the trustees of Heatherton School Section.

Apart from the justifiableness of the request, which I believe to be sound, the argument that appeals to me is the one of benefits to the Indian children accruing from associating with white children during their school days. The Indians of the Heatherton and Summerside Reservations are rapidly emulating the customs and habits of the white people. This is a good and important fact in our plan, fostered by having Indian children attend Provincial Schools. The industry, application and progress in study of the white children will act as an excellent stimulus to those from the Reservations while the imitation of the native children's deportment and refinement will be salutary. For such benefits it would appear to me that your Department would be favourably disposed to assisting in a very definite way the establishing of a thoroughly modern school at Heatherton.

At any rate, being extremely interested in educational work, particularly at Heatherton, I shall anxiously await your decision in the matter.

Respectfully yours,

Sir,

The enclosed letter, or report, relates to a matter, which arrested my attention when I visited the Indian settlement at Tuft's Cove, N.S., recently.

I found a good school in operation there, conducted by a young man of leisure, who, therefore, having time on his hands, and wishing to make good use of it by assisting in some manner those most in need of help, decided to open a school among the Indians of Dartmouth at their request. He did so without hope of remuneration, or reward - other than comes to one who is conscious of having done his full duty towards fellow mortals, who may require such assistance as he is in a position to give.

I visited the school and was so impressed with what I saw, that I requested Mr. Richardson to send me a statement explaining the circumstances under which the school was opened and kept in operation; and I regard it as incumbent on me to bring the matter to the notice of the Department.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that the building used as a school house at Tufts Cove, N.S., was erected for that purpose last Spring by the Indians residing there, and was intended for temporary occupation only. It serves the purpose well enough during warm and temperate weather, but in order to keep the school in operation for the full term, as is desirable, the building should be improved considerably to make it habitable for the winter.

An expenditure of about $40, mostly for tar-paper, shingles, and nails, would be required to make it comfortable for pupils and teacher in the cold weather season, and I recommend that the amount be authorized by the Department for purchasing materials, as stated. The Indians would furnish the necessary labour to put the building in good condition.

I recommend also that the Department furnish the school with fuel; but I do not think it necessary to appoint a janitor, because the Indians have a lively interest in the school and will, I believe, keep it clean and make a fire in the room every morning without being paid to do so.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am sorry that your letter of some time ago concerning the education of the Indian children residing in Rocky Point Reservation has remained so long unanswered, and I fear that even now after looking into the matter pretty fully I am still unable to offer you a satisfactory solution of the difficulty.

As I understand the matter, an Indian Reservation has been established at Rocky Point. While the number of Indians residing there permanently is not very large nor the number of children of school age very great, these numbers are increased in summer considerably by transient residents.

The white people of the District object to the presence in their school of the Indian children chiefly for two reasons. First, because of the prevalence of tuberculosis in the Indian encampment and the unsanitary condition of the Indian homes the close association of the Indian children with the other children of the District might be a menace to the health of the community. Second, it is claimed that the responsibility for the education of the Indian children living on a Government Reservation rests with the Indian Department and not with the school District which may happen to be near the Reservation.

After giving the matter careful consideration I do not think that the Education Department, though desirous that Indian children should have the very best educational facilities possible, would be justified in trying to compel the school authorities at Rocky Point to admit to the privileges of their school the Indian children living

Mr. Scott,

The question of affording educational facilities for the Indian children residing at Rocky Point, Prince Edward Island, has been before the Department for some time. There is a small reserve there of three acres, which was purchased from Mr. Newson to accommodate two Indian families who had been stopping there for the past thirty years. There is a white school adjacent to the reserve and application was made to the trustees to permit the few Indian children to attend this school. The trustees refused and the matter was brought to the attention of the Prince Edward Island government. Hon. Mr. Matheson, Attorney General for the province, took the matter up personally and had an interview with the people of the district and the Education Department and has tried to bring about an agreement for the admission of these children, but he was unable to overcome the opposition of the white settlers. just forwarded a letter received by him from the Superintendent of Education for the province, in which he states that he is unable to offer any satisfactory solution of the difficulty, as he does not think they would be justified in trying to compel the school authorities there to admit Indian children to the school.

The chief objection of the white settlers is that the Indian children come from tubercular surroundings. During the summer time a number of Indians camp on this reserve and judging from the correspondence they are not an acquisition to the place, as they live in a very primitive manner and take no sanitary precautions. These visitors are from the Morell Reserve and as long as they come there nothing much can be done to improve conditions.

There are not enough Indian children resident on the three acre reserve to justify the Department in establishing a school and it would be cheaper and more to the children's advantage to place them in some residential school, if one could be found on the Island. Rev. Father McDonald, Indian Superintendent, has forwarded your letter of the 22nd ultimo addressed to him on the question of the education of the Indian children residing on the Rocky Point Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is indebted to you and the Attorney General for the interest you have taken in this matter and it feels that you have done all in your power to try to have a satisfactory arrangement entered into with the school trustees for the education of these Indian children at the white school near the reserve. As your united efforts have failed to overcome the objection of the whites to the co-education of Indian children in their school, the Department has written to Father McDonald asking him to find out whether there is any residential school in the province where the children could be received and, if so, on what terms.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Charlottetown, P.E.I.
Sir,

If funds sufficient were available I would like to see a small school house erected on the Reserve at Rocky Point.

There are seven or eight pupils that permanently derive of the benefits of education. A school building could be built and a teacher could be obtained for about $200. a year. It would be cheaper than to have them sent away for education and more instructively, as most of the children would be too young to be sent to boarding schools, nor sent to board where other schools. The school building could be erected on the three acres of land near the houses. Besides the permanent resident there are always many other children coming there with their parents. The school could be also used for religious instruction on Sundays.

Sir,

The School at Rocky Point is in an awful muddle. They built a little school house and now are claiming $175.00 from the Department for it. Louis Mitchell and Peter Skully constitute themselves trustees and made matters worse. Matilda Latrobe, the girl who was teaching had a hard time. She started to board with Louis Mitchell and found the board poor also. Louis' children were tubercular. She left there and went to board at Alice Mitchell's. This gave great offense to Louis and Peter Skully. As you see by enclosed letters they state that she left the school. I went down last week to investigate and induced Miss Latrobe to go back to the school. I consulted Father Maurice McDaniel of the Cartier and found it was not true that Matilda left. She changed boarding house only and they looked the school and refused to let her enter. Peter Skully wanted to get back teaching but he is not very well educated. I concluded that it would be well to close the school altogether for the present as they cannot agree among themselves. I would recommend that Louis Mitchell be not paid as junior and that Matilda Latrobe be paid for one month. She taught three weeks and had the trouble and expense of being back last week about 80 miles.

Dear Sir:

A few days ago J. H. Sapier, Indian, returned soldier and a teacher in the Indian school, applied to me for treatment. I telephoned Dr. Garrison, and he informs me that Sapier's case is one of arrested tuberculosis. However, I find upon examination that some metabolic change is going on. He is carrying a temperature and suffering from a severe pain in his right side.

Today I communicated with Dr. Jenkins, and am informed that he is drawing a full pension as a T.B. Therefore, I consider it quite indiscreet that he should be given the school at Rocky Point, in his own interest as well as in the interest of the colony. OTTAWA, January 26th, 1922.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a communication from J. H. Sepier, teacher of the Rocky Point Indian Day School, in which he requests that residence be provided for the teacher's use in connection with this school. He states that there is a vacant house formerly occupied by Mrs. Susan Bernard which could be obtained but that it would require to be furnished.

I will be pleased if you will advise as soon as possible whether you consider that the teacher's request be complied with. I may say that the Department has little funds for purposes of this kind and, unless there is no other accommodation for a teacher, it would not be disposed to incur any expenditure for the purpose of furnishing a residence.

Last term there were 13 children enrolled and for that number of children the building was large enough. Since then two other families have been added to the reserve with a consequent increase in the number of the children attending school, and now the building is too small to hold them comfortably. If this attendance is kept up there will be need for the Department to erect a suitable building.

The Playgrounds are inadequate.

Owing to contracted quarters the calisthenics exercises are not able to take place in the school room and unless the weather is favourable, cannot take place outside, which I consider a drawback to the general health and development physically of the children, as where these exercises are regularly given much good results.

Jno. J. Ryan

Inspector.
Ottawa, January 5, 1912.

Rev. Sir,

Referring to that portion of your report on the Edmundston Indian Day School in which you deal with the accommodation I beg to say that the information in the possession of the Department shows that this school-room is 18 by 20, providing thereby accommodation for twenty-three pupils. The returns from this school for the past three quarters show that the average attendance has been respectively 11, 12 and 16 and the highest enrolment has been 21. Under the circumstances the Department does not consider that it should be necessary to take any steps to erect a new building at the present time. It is granted that the calisthenics cannot be taken in the school-room when the full enrolment is present, but in any event whenever possible these exercises should be taken out of doors.

The Department is pleased to learn from your report on this school that such satisfactory work is being done.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J. J. Ryan,
Bupt. of Indian Schools,

WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW ABOUT BEAVER BOARD

Description: Beaver Board is used chiefly for the place of lath, plaster and other wall materials for building materials. Because of its superior surface for decorating, it makes wallpaper unnecessary. It is made of wood pulp, which is mixed with water and pressed into panels. Beaver board reduces the need for lath and plaster, making walls easier to paint and maintain.

Application: Beaver Board is nailed to the studs of new rooms or directly over the lath and plaster of old rooms. The panels are easily cut with a fine tooth saw, sharp knife or chisel.

Advantages:
1. Beaver Board does not chip, crack or disintegrate.
2. It makes rooms appear larger and more spacious.
3. It improves with age; never needs repainting.
4. It is easy to install.

Sizes: Dealers carry Beaver Board in 3', 4', 5', 6', 7', 8' and 10' widths by 4', 5', 6', 7', 8' lengths.

Decoration: Beaver Board can be painted or stained to match existing decor. It can also be used as a base for wallpaper or other finishes.

Accessories: Accessories such as trim, molding, plate rail, etc., can be purchased from local dealers.

Dr. Sir,

This following is my final report on the Indian School House recently built on the Indian Reserve at Edmundston by one L. Garnier Contractor.

Character of Work:
The Contractor and his representative gave personal and constant attention to the work at the building in the most satisfactory manner and in accordance with drawings and specifications.

Deviation:
No deviation or change was made by the contractor from the drawings or specifications.

Material:
All material was new and of an approved quality and no defective material was put in building.

Measurements:
The Contractor strictly followed plan furnished by Department Site.

Site:
The Contractor examined the site where the building was erected and removed all obstructions except an old log hut that the builder had used for shelter. This hut could not be removed but will be used as soon as the hay can be taken out.

Superfluous Material:
All superfluous material was removed by the Contractor and the ground in front and around the school house was levelled.

Quality of Work:
All the work was done in a most satisfactory manner.

Extras:
No extras were asked for by the Contractor and none offered although the Contractor did considerable extra work and furnished extra material so the job would be complete and first class.

Foundation:
Foundation was made of concrete, the proportion one to six was used and the gravel and sand used was clean and first class and a number one foundation was made.

Chimney:
The chimney was built as shown on plan and specification.

Nails, Beams, Joists, Bridging, Frame, Work, Wall, Studs, Sills, Girts, Angle Bracing, Roof, were all up to contract and specification.

Sheeting, Paper, was put in every place named in specification and of the quality asked for.

Shingle Roofing:
The roof was covered with the best quality of cedar shingles laid as directed by specification.

First Floor:
First floor was covered with No. I Matched Spruce nailed with 3 inch nails.

Second Floor:
Second floor was covered with No. I grooved and tongued red birch.

All Doors and Windows were trimmed according to specification.

Wainscoting:
Wainscoting the class room was done 4 ft high and with the best of No. I hard pine and a suitable cap was put on.

Metal Ceiling:
Metal ceiling of the class room, cloak, and teachers rooms were finished up with metal sheathing according to specification.

Windows, Frames, and Door Frames:
All window frames and door frames were made and placed according to specification likewise inside doors that were required were made and placed as requested by specification.

Exterior and Interior Doors were made and hung with specified hinges and brass faced locks.

[Signature]
T.M. Richards
Inspector
Outside Steps

The Outside Steps and Porches were built and strongly constructed and the Roofs of said Porches were made the same as specified in Specification, and the Outside Flooring on said Porches were of 1 1/2 inch Grooved Tongued Dry Spruce of best quality.

Winter Sashes.

Winter Sashes were made and adjusted to their proper places as requested by specification.

Screen Doors & Screen Sashes were furnished by the Contractor and adjusted to their places according to Specification.

Blinds.

Blinds attached to self rolling sticks were furnished and adjusted in every Window.

Cloak Rooms.

Cloak Rooms were furnished with the five Doz. wire Hat & Cloak Hooks.

Platform.

Platform was built in class Room according to Specification.

Black Board.

Black Board of the best quality of Slate is being installed by the Contractor.

Molding for Pictures.

Molding for Pictures was installed as requested.

Plastering.

All the walls and partitions were lathed according to Specification. The first coat of Plaster was of Celanite and the second coat was of plaster Paris. I must say I never saw a better job than this. I am now nearly 70 years of age and been into building more or less all my life.

PAINTING.

The painting was done in a most satisfactory manner.

The Material was first class. All the outside of the School House received three coats of Non I White Lead.

The painting on the inside was done in Workman Ship Manner.

The Hard Wood Floors were oiled twice and one coat of Shellack.

The Roof and all the Shingle Work received two coats of Light Green Creasote and was well applied.

Window Glass.

All the Window Glass was according to Specification.

Ventilations.

Ventilations in Chimney and in Class Room and in Cloak Rooms were all installed according to Specification.

Correction.

I am much pleased to state that I had the old Log Hut that the old Indian had his Hay in removed to day. I sent my Team and Men and hauled the hay for the old Indian to a place he provided for same. This Old Log Hut was so close to the School House recently built that it was quite dangerous for fire.

J.M. Richards,
Inspector

Sir,

I beg to advise you that the entrance door of the school house at Edmundston need repairing. The door was broken last spring and the teacher then reported the matter to Mr. Waite who promised to have it repaired, but the matter was never attended to. Miss Michaud states that it is not safe to leave any longer in its present condition, as it cannot be shut and it is almost impossible to keep the school warm. Miss Michaud states that she can get the man who built the school to repair it, if the Department will pay for the repairs. I have today written Miss Michaud to have this man repair the door immediately and to send me his bill for same in duplicate, and I trust that this will be satisfactory to the Department, and that they will give me authority to have the repairs made.

Your obedient servant,
