Sir,

I am in receipt of yours of the 25th inst., re. voucher No. 338 amounting to $6.53 in favor of T. M. Richards for supplies furnished to the Edmundston day school and note your remarks re. same. You ask me to notify the teacher that unauthorized accounts will not be paid in future. I beg to advise you that I authorized this expenditure when I was at Edmundston some time ago, but possibly omitted writing you re. same. If at any time I should be in Edmundston or the teacher should write me from there wanting school supplies, or if the teacher from the Tobique Reserve should do likewise, as I not to grant permission to get the things that are absolutely necessary for the school at once without writing to Ottawa first? It would seem to me to be almost unnecessary that a man be appointed as Indian agent, if a three or four dollar expenditure is wanted hurriedly, that he cannot give the order without first writing away consulting the Dept. If this is the case I don't understand why an agent would be necessary at all, as the school teacher or whoever might want the goods could write direct to the Dept. and get permission direct from them.
I beg to advise you that certain repairs are necessary on the school house at Edmonton. There are four panes of glass broken in the windows and one in the front door, the one in the front door being broken recently by the wind. I also wish to advise you that the closets were damaged by the frost last winter and require repair. The doors cannot be kept closed and the hinges are broken. I am not just sure what it will take to have the necessary repairs made, but would judge that $15.00 or $16.00 would cover expenses.

Please authorize this expenditure so that the necessary repairs can be made immediately.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy & Sec'y of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

The school requires painting inside and the out houses white washed and repaired.

The school also requires a good washing and the grounds should be better cared for.
Ottawa, July 19, 1920.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Ryan, in a report on his recent inspection of the Edmundston Indian Day School, states that the inside of the school requires to be painted and that the outhouses should be repaired and whitewashed. He also states that the floor of the schoolroom requires a good washing and that the woodwork inside should also be cleaned. He states that the grounds should be better cared for.

I have to request that you will be good enough to obtain an estimate of the cost of having the inside walls of the school alabastined and the woodwork painted, also the outhouses whitewashed and the necessary repairs made. You should give this matter your prompt attention and forward the price you obtain for having this work done at an early date, in order that, if it is decided to go ahead with the work, it may be done during the present summer holidays.

You should at once take steps to have the floor and woodwork cleaned and also to have the ground around the school building cleaned up. The washing of the floor and woodwork and the cleaning of the grounds should be done at the lowest possible expense.

The Department will expect an early reply as to the cost of the painting and whitewashing.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. B. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

N. J. Wootten, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Perth, N.B.
Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter 66-1-5 of the 19th inst. regarding the Edmundston Indian Day School. I have been to Edmundston, and looked over the school, and find that school ceiling requires re-painting, and the walls need to be slubastined. The woodwork does not require any painting, but just a good cleaning. The out-houses need to be white-washed, and considerable repairs are also necessary. I have endeavored to get an estimate from different parties at Edmundston for doing the work, but could get only one man to furnish an estimate. His name is Honors [illegible], and he has agreed to give the ceiling of the school-room, the two coat-rooms, and the entrance, two coats of white paint, and to re-paint and calamine the walls, also to replace all broken glass in the windows of the school-room, and to repair the back door of the school, and to white-wash the two out-houses, repair the steps of same, also two doors and seat covers, also to furnish a new lock for the back door of the school house. He is to furnish all other material necessary for doing this work for the sum of $160.00. I think his estimate is a reasonable one, and I have been informed that he is a very reliable man and has the reputation of doing good work in a very satisfactory manner; therefore I trust that you will advise me by return mail as to whether you want the work done or not, as he will have to plan the other work so as to go to work on the school on the Reserve as soon as possible.
Sir,

I have also made arrangements with Mrs. Noel Bernard to wash all the floors and all the woodwork in the school after the other work is completed, for the sum of $4.00.

Regarding the cleaning of the grounds I will say that the grounds are not in a very bad condition, with the exception that there is some hay that requires cutting. I have arranged with Mr. Fred Michaud, of Edmundston, to clean up the ground for the privilege of cutting the hay that is on it. I trust that this will prove to your satisfaction.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

With reference to your letter of the 2nd instant and previous correspondence regarding the land purchased from Joseph Trombly for a school site on the Edmundston Reserve, I beg to say the account for $65.00 which you submitted from Mr. T. M. Richards, the contractor, for payment made to Joseph Trombly can not be considered, as the deed for the school site (1½ acres of land) has not been completed. You were informed in the Department's letter of the 11th August last that upon the completion of the deed Joseph Trombly would be paid the balance ($65.00) due from the land. According to Mr. Richards' report, when you visited the Edmundston Reserve on the 14th August last you did not carry out the Department's instructions to pay Trombly, on account, the $10.00 sent you for him, but you gave instructions, it is understood, to Mr. Richards to furnish provisions to the Indians, and you paid to the latter the amount due Trombly. You were not justified in your action. The cheque should have been given to Joseph Trombly when he signed the agreement to sell. It is also understood that you authorized Mr. Richards to issue relief to Joseph Trombly on account of his purchase money, and it is understood from Mr. Richards that the amount has been fully used up. The land belonged to

S. P. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Andover, N. B.
to the Indian, and when the deed is completed Joseph Trombly is entitled to payment of the balance due, namely, $65.00. Mr. Richards can not be recognized by the Department in the transaction. It is necessary for you to explain why you requested Mr. Richards to pay the Indian $5.00 on account when you had in your possession a cheque for $10.00 due the Indian, and why at a later date you handed this cheque over to Mr. Richards. The money should not have been placed in the merchant's hands, particularly in view of the fact that the Indian is a responsible, sober man, and can manage his own affairs, and also is entitled, as above stated, to receive payment for his land.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I am in receipt of yours of the 1st inst advising me to furnish the Department with an estimate of the cost to raise and drain the school grounds at Edmundston, in connection with the Edmundston school, also to furnish you with an estimate of the probable cost of fencing these grounds. I have been to Edmundston, and gone into the matter as much as I possibly could, and from the condition of the ground, I firmly believe that the cost of raising and draining these grounds would very much exceed what the Department anticipates. Knowing very little about this sort of thing I could not furnish you with an estimate, as I was unable while at Edmundston to get any person who could give me an estimate of the work. No doubt the Government at Ottawa have men who make a business of this sort of thing, and by coming and looking it over could map out the work they want done in an intelligent manner, and I believe have it done more cheaply than a person who knew nothing whatever about it could do, and I believe that it would be a saving to the Department to send a man to look the situation over.

The teacher is very anxious to do a little farming, and I have given her an order to get some farming implements such as a hoe, spade, and rake also an order for some seed. She thinks that everything together will not exceed from $12.00 to $15.00, and I have given her permission to employ a farmer to plough up a piece of land in the rear of the school so that she can get her gardening done. I trust the Department will approve of my action as the season is getting so late, I could not await a reply from Ottawa before having the work done.

I expect in the course of a few days to be able to furnish you with an estimate for fencing the grounds. It will take about 1500 ft. of wire, as the land is about an acre square.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th inst. enclosing one from Mr. Collins, teacher of the New School at School relative to the grant of the June quarter last.

On examination of the returns for the four quarters of the present year 1893-4 shows that the holidays exclusive of Saturday & Sunday allowed the school for that period were:

| Quarter       | Days |
|---------------|------|
| September     | 1893 | 6    |
| October       | 1893 | 7    |

or four days more than the school was entitled to. This arose through an oversight when preparing the voucher in connection with the June 1894 Return, of the fact that an additional four days had been allowed Mr. Collins for the March quarter as well as the grant for that quarter up to $75.00. If the teacher or workers
this overpayment to him can be adjusted in connection with his next returns in the event of the school being reopened.

During the fiscal year 1893-94 the school was open:

- September quarter 1893: 38 days
- December 1893: 57 days
- March 1894: 58 days
- June 1894: 44 days

Total 199 days.

The school should therefore have been kept open another 16 days, in all 215 for the year ending June 30th, 1894 in order to draw a $75.00 grant for the last quarter or $300.00 for that year. Owing to there being 53 Saturdays in 1893-94 there were only 215 school days instead of 216.

With reference to Mr. Callin remarks that he asked for 20 holidays instead of 17 I would quote the following from his return: "Please count these 17 days as holidays. It will thus be seen that as far from Mr. Collins having a claim against the Department he is indebted to it to the amount of 7 days' pay or £8.08.

Archdeacon Yaray desires to discuss in particular four matters:

1. The application which has been informally made by the Bishop of Saskatchewan for a school at Lac la Ronge.

The census shows there are 46 Indians belonging to Lac la Ronge band, 475 of whom are returned as Anglicans and 18 as Roman Catholics. There is a day school conducted under the auspices of the Church of England. It has an enrollment of 28 pupils and an average attendance of 12. Inspector Chisholm visited the school last year and reported the teacher was not a success owing to his slight knowledge of English. He reported the building large, comfortable and in good order. As the Indians of the Lac la Ronge country lead a roving life it is impossible to secure a large attendance at the day school. When the Bishop brought the matter up you
did not feel that we should at present go further in the direction of providing Boarding Schools.

2. Increased grant for Emmanuel College and a contribution for repairs and equipment.

This school has had a $1000.00 during the current year for repairs to the building. It is a Boarding School and gets a capitation grant of $72.00 for 32 pupils and a capitation grant of $100.00 for 20 pupils. This extra grant was allowed for the training of teachers, but the Department reports that that work has been a practical failure, and that on no other ground is the school entitled to a larger per capita grant than the ordinary boarding school, as it does not do more in the direction of manual training than other boarding schools. The request was therefore refused although pressed more than once by Mr Davis.

3. Reopening of the day school on the Stony Reserve and Pattleford Agency: This school was closed at the end of 1890 with a view to having the
pupils attend the Rattleford Industrial School on the Stony Reserves. These Reserves form a group of three with a population of 86, 4 of whom are returned as Anglican and the balance as Pagans. The Church of England has a day school on Red Pheasant's Reserve in the same Agency. There is no money available for the payment of teacher if this school were reopened, and before taking steps to provide the necessary funds it might be well to have a report from the agent and inspector upon the desirability of reopening this school. Unless a fair number of the 86 Indians are settled down from a roving life, it would be hard to successfully conduct a day school.

4. Increased remuneration for Mrs Matheson:
Mrs Matheson is the wife of the Principal of the Boarding School at Onion Lake. She is a qualified physician, is paid $100.00 for giving medical attendance to the Indians of Onion Lake. The Department supplies the medicines which cost about an equal amount. Mr Smart declined to give an increase
in October last on the ground that there was no money available and the same ground now exists as the appropriation for medical work is about as heavily taxed as it can stand.

Sir,

In reply to your letters above quoted, regarding the reopening of the day school on the Stony reserve in this agency, I have the honor to report as follows:

There is no change in the attitude of these Indians towards the Industrial School, and it is apparent that for some time to come education cannot reach them through the medium of any class of school situated abroad from the reserve.

They have, on the other hand, repeatedly expressed a desire to have the day school reopened, and the conditions for day school work are in some respects favorable. There are at present nineteen children of school age, and eleven under six years.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
The twenty-one families composing the band occupy dwellings so situated that none are more than a quarter of a mile from a central point. In about two months during laying, however, they camp at their hay swamps, from three to five miles distant, and during that period school would necessarily be suspended. A few weeks be a break from a similar cause during seeding and harvest.

The main difficulty in connection with the reopening of this school would be to procure a properly qualified and otherwise suitable teacher. Such a person should not fall below the Department's requirements in respect to education and training; he should be married, as there is no convenient place for a single person to live; and he should have a dwelling within or adjacent to the encampment. To establish a teacher where there have unusual opportunities for influencing the lives and habits of the Indians.

There is no school building or teacher's dwelling at the present encampment. The
old school house is at the old farm, five miles distant, and could not be removed with advantage, though some of the material of which it is constructed could be utilized in the erection of a new building, as it is of course whatever place it is. The old farm house also, which is about half a mile from the school, might be taken down and the material turned to account in the building of a new school and teacher's dwelling.

Assuming that none but a duly qualified teacher will be put in charge I have no hesitation in recommending the reopening of this school.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

The Secretary:

When Archdeacon Mackay was here in April last he applied, inter alia, for the re-opening of the day school on the Stony Reserve in the Battleford Agency (Eagle Hills) and by direction of the Minister Inspector Ghisholm was asked to report as to the advisability of re-opening this school. His report has now been received in which he states that the only way to educate these Indians is through the medium of a day school on the reserve as they are opposed to industrial schools. There are 15 children of school age whose parents all live within convenient distance of a central point where a school could be established, but there is no suitable place for a teacher to live nor is there a building fit for school purposes. Mr Ghisholm thinks that a properly qualified or otherwise suitable teacher would have unusual opportunities for influencing the lives and habits of these Indians.

The question now resolves itself to one of expenditure. Five hundred dollars would have to be provided for a teacher's salary and an appropriation would be required for the erection of a suitable schoolhouse and teacher's dwelling combined, which would cost a considerable amount in this isolated locality.

NORTH SASKATCHEWAN INSPECTORATE,

Prince Albert, April 23rd, 1910.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of Feb. 1st, No. 352400/1, regarding the application of the Indians of Moosomin's band for the establishment of a day school on their new reserve, I have the honour to state that on the 2nd inst. I visited the reserve and looked into the question from different points of view, and am now in a position to report on the subject.

The Indians, it is true, are anxious to have a school on the reserve, now that they are farther removed from the residential schools which in many instances their children attended in the past. The center of the reserve is about 30 miles from the Battleford Industrial School and about 50 miles from Thunderchild's Boarding School.

There are 21 children of school age on the reserve, namely, 11 boys and 10 girls, including 2 who are members of Thunderchild's band but who are likely to be permanent residents of this reserve. Of the 21 children of school age here indicated a few are approaching 16 years and would probably not attend school; so that the actual school attendance under favourable conditions would probably be 15 or 16 pupils, unless this were further reduced through some being persuaded to send their children to the boarding institutions. So long as the Indians have an option between two or more school the attendance at any one cannot be definitely counted upon.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
The parents of a large majority of these children are Roman Catholics, or have a preference for that religion, although many have, I understand, at one time or another been baptized as Anglicans. Although the Indians would, themselves, probably not object to a non-denominational school, yet it is doubtful whether any school other than a Roman Catholic one would be successful. My main reasons for discussing this question, there being no question as to the religion of the majority, are that in the case of undenominational schools there is a much larger range of choice in the selection of a teacher, and that no pretext is afforded to any section to hold themselves aloof on religious grounds. These considerations are, however, so important that in case it were decided to open a day school on this reserve it might be advisable to take the matter up with his Lordship Bishop Pascal, with a view to securing, if possible, a permanent understanding regarding an undenominational school here; for if the consent of the Bishop is secured no objection will arise from the Indians.

As the dwellings of the Indians are at present distributed throughout the reserve there are 14 children at the south-west end, near the shore of Murray Lake; there are 6 about the center of the reserve; and one at the north-east end. If this were permanent a school would be best situated at the south-west end, where the majority live; but the present conditions have no appearance of permanence. It seems, in fact, fairly certain that in the near future a larger number will locate near the center of the reserve, which is 3 or 4 miles from either end; and until the Agent and Farmer get their ideas worked out more maturely and get the Indians to select farm sites and build more substantial buildings, it will be impossible to decide with any degree of certainty as to where a school can be most advantageously situated. With two or three exceptions
the present dwellings are all mere temporary shacks, - new and clean, it is true, but still mere shanties and in many instances not intended to be occupied longer than the first winter. Only 40 acres of land was broken last season, and at the time of my visit not more than half a dozen were fully decided as to where they would locate their farms. It seems probable that when the Indians are once settled down to their industries the center of population will be somewhere near the center of the reserve, where, partly for this reason, it has been decided to locate the farm buildings.

In view of the circumstances as described above I would respectfully recommend that though the necessity for a school on this reserve be recognized yet action toward the establishment of the same be deferred at least until next winter, when if it be deemed advisable plans can be laid for the following season.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Referring to your letter quoted above, and also that of Jan. 31st, relative to the establishment of a day school on the Moosomin reserve at Murray Lake, I have the honour to report as follows:

There can be no doubt as to the need for a school on this reserve, or the anxiety of the Indians to have one established. During a brief visit which I made here toward the end of March the Indians again brought up the matter. I discussed it with the Agent, who was, however, as yet too new to his duties to have a definite opinion on the subject. The main difficulty is to determine where a school can be located so as to serve to the best advantage the entire band, having some regard to probable future conditions.

The reserve is so uniform throughout in respect to facilities afforded for the industries of the band, no part being particularly well suited for either grain growing or cattle raising, that the Indians are, I judge, liable to move from time to time in an effort to improve conditions. However, such removals will only be in individual cases; and it is probable that a school situated centrally at the present time will continue to be fairly central in the future, so long as the boundaries of the reserve remain as they are at present.

About two-thirds of the members of the band have

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
abodes in the west end of the reserve, about two miles or two and a half from Murray Lake. The farm house is located about the center of the reserve; and the remainder of the Indians are between the farm and the east end, in two small groups. However the population may fluctuate as to location, it seems most likely that the larger section of the band will continue to live within two or three miles of Murray Lake.

Yet for this season I would hesitate to recommend the erection of buildings of a permanent character for school purposes. Unless the school were situated conveniently near to the farm house or the mission a teacher's dwelling as well as a school house would be required, and the expense involved would be considerable, even though the buildings should be constructed of logs. Father Lacombe informs me that he has two qualified teachers in view; and he volunteers to furnish a building to serve as a school-room. I have no doubt he has communicated this offer to the Department; and I expect he has in view that the teacher should occupy the dwelling in connection with the mission, which is situated on the border of the reserve, about two and a half miles north-west from the farm house and about a mile and a half from the lake. The school-room would also be in connection with the mission; and it would thus be from half a mile to two miles from the homes of the larger portion of the band referred to above as dwelling at the west end of the reserve. I believe that with the attractions of the improved school a fair attendance of the children from this end of the reserve could be secured at a school so situated; and I would accordingly recommend that the offer and suggestion of Father Lacombe be adopted. This would furnish a fair opportunity for the Indians to show their appreciation of a school; and if the experiment proved satisfactory to the Department preparations could be made
for the erection, next season possibly, of suitable buildings within the limits of the reserve.

If it were necessary, from present data and indications, to select at once a site for permanent school buildings on this reserve, I would recommend a point approximately one mile south of the mission and about a mile and a half from the lake.

Provided the Indians show sufficient interest in the school after a trial, it seems to me it would be advisable to construct buildings after the description of those being erected on Little Pine's reserve; for it is unlikely that henceforth any of the children of this band, except an occasional orphan, will be sent elsewhere to school, and with the present school population of this band and the number of small children coming up to school age there is increasing scope for a useful day school.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir,

With further reference to your letter of the 21st ult., regarding the opening of a school on the Moosomin reserve, I have the honour to state that the person whom Rev. Father Lacombe recommends for appointment as teacher is Albert Edward Rotsey, who has latterly been farming near Jackfish Lake, a few miles from the reserve. Mr. Rotsey is 40 years of age, is married and has a small family, all his children being under ten years of age.

For 13 years he was a soldier in the British army, enlisting at 20 years of age and retiring of his own accord at 33. His record in the army is favourable, and during his term of service he passed an examination for promotion and was promoted to the rank of corporal. A Second Class certificate for attainments in elementary military education was issued to him on an examination embracing "Writing to dictation; Arithmetic; Reduction of Weights and Measures; simple Practice and Proportion; Vulgar and Decimal Fractions; Percentages and Averages; arranging and balancing Regimental and other Accounts". On enlisting he was entered as a Dentist by profession; he was assigned to a medical staff corps, and at Aldershot he passed a class of instruction for "Qualified Cook in a Military Hospital" and also for "Compounder of Medicines". He was born and brought up at Boulogne, France; and was formerly, and presumably still is, a member of the Church of England.

The foregoing information, along with much of less importance, I have from certificates of the Officers of the Regiment in which the applicant served. I know Mr. Rotsey, but not intimately. He is a man of fair intelligence; and I have a favourable impression as to his character and qualifications; but lacking as

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

He does both special training for teaching and experience in the work I could not speak with confidence regarding his success. I would think, however, it would not be amiss to give him a trial: if he only proves diligent and interested in his duties he will likely succeed.

Father Lacombe is anxious that a salary allowance of $500 per annum should be made by the Department; as he claims it is impossible to secure a teacher for less. As Mr. Rotsey has considerable skill in the handling of medicines it might be that an allowance of $400 as teacher and $100 as dispenser would be an advantageous arrangement. There is at present no supply of medicines on the reserve; but as this band is now isolated and visits by the medical attendant are few and unsatisfactory, I believe that a well chosen assortment of medicines in the hands of a man with Mr. Rotsey's qualifications would be the means of effecting a great improvement in the present condition of things.

I presume fuel will be supplied for the school; and Father Lacombe inquires whether the Department will make some allowance for the cooking of the children's noon meal. The request is also made that the conveying of the children to and from the school be provided for. However, this question might, I think, be laid over until the approach of winter. In the meantime I shall ascertain and advise the Department as to the exact dimensions of the school-room, and as to whether the entire school population could be accommodated in case a full attendance were secured.

Referring to your letter quoted above, regarding the opening of a day school on the Moosomin reserve, I have the honour to report further as follows:

The building which Rev. Father Lacombe offers to loan temporarily for school purposes is situated on the SW quarter of sec. 32, tp 47, rge 16, west of the 3rd mer., and while not on either reserve is as close as possible to both the Moosomin and Saulteaux reserves. It is possible that some of the Saulteaux may be induced to avail themselves of its advantages. There are between 15 and 20 Saulteaux children of school age, some of whom live less than a mile from this building and some between 2 and 3 miles.

This building I find to be closer to the Moosomin Indians' dwellings than I formerly reported. Including a family from Bear's Hille who are making their home here, there are 22 children of school age on this reserve, of whom 14 are between half a mile and a mile from this building. The remaining 8 are from 4 to 6 miles distant, and belong to four families.

The building in question was built for church and dwelling for missionary under one roof. It is 34' x 28' in dimensions, and consists of two storeys, with a small but secure cellar. It is constructed of lumber, and is as yet unpainted. It has a substantial stone foundation, though only on the surface, being 3 feet high and 2 ft. in thickness.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
The proposed class-room, which is the room provided for church services, is in the second storey and is the full size of the building, being 34' x 25' and with a ceiling averaging 9 ft. in height, being 10 ft. in the center. There are two entrances and two corresponding stairs, leading to this room.

The first storey is divided into six apartments, five of which will be available for school purposes, namely, four rooms for teacher's quarters and one for pupils' dining-room, while the remaining apartment is retained by Father Lacombe as his private room and study.

The pupils' dining-room is 15'7" x 12', and can be provided with tables in such a way as to seat conveniently 16, or if necessary 20, children. The other rooms, including the kitchen, are 11'6" x 8'8".

The building is heated by stoves; and there is a well constructed brick chimney from the ground up.

Mrs. Rotsey, wife of the teacher whose appointment has been approved, is willing to attend to the preparation of the children's noon meal, but would expect $10 per month for this duty, as she understands that this remuneration has been allowed in some other instances.

I beg to report as follows.

On the 24th Nov 1913, along with Inspector Chisholm, I visited Buffalo Lake School and found it closed. We were informed by the Teacher, Mr A. E. Natesy, that the School had been closed since the 17th of that month, owing to the misbehaviour of one of the pupils Harriet Nyo. He informed us that his wife objected to having this pupil at school, on account of what she termed indecent conduct. Upon our suggestion, Mr Natesy offered to discipline the child, but his wife refused to have anything to do with the school, so long as this child remained. We were compelled to interview the parents Mr & Mrs Nyo, and in the interests of the school to request that for a while they keep the child at home.

Nyo brought his child to school, and she denied all charges in the presence of Mr Natesy, Inspector Chisholm and myself. Notwithstanding the statements of the Teacher and his wife that the child was acting innocently, we judged the conduct of the child was no worse than any other Indian child of her age, and could easily have been overcome with a little strict discipline.

SCHOOLS BRANCH

FEB 8 1914
Upon making further inquiry we were informed from a reliable source, that the whole trouble arose from the hysterical nature of Mrs Rotsey, which we have every reason to believe was so.

There was not sufficient evidence to justify suspension, but in the interests of the school and to prevent the closing of same, we thought it advisable to get the parents to keep the child at home for the present.

On the 13th inst., the Rev Father Lecoube, who is in charge of the Catholic Schools of this Agency called at my Office to see Inspector Chisholm and myself concerning school matters. We held a long conversation over the Murray Lake School, and he made the statement that we would have to replace Mr Rotsey as teacher, in order to bring the school along successfully. Owing to the attitude of Mrs Rotsey above referred to, Mr Rotsey's usefulness as a teacher is greatly impaired, and his services cannot long be continued. I might add that Rev Father Lecoube, is in a particularly favourable position to express an opinion on this matter, owing to the fact that he resides for the greater part of his time, in the same house along with Mr and Mrs Rotsey.

Dear Sir,

In the Report of the Superintendent of Indian Education for the year ended March 31, 1813, on page 365, Mr. J.A. Rawland, Indian agent, reports as follows on Inverness Day School:

"I am unable to report as to the progress made by these children, as on the four occasions on which I visited this school, it was closed, and there were no children present."

Now, I beg to state that the above report is entirely false. Mr. Rawland never came to visit the school on school days, or during school hours. His visits were on holidays, or after school hours. Did the Agent make this false statement wilfully or not; it does not matter. There is a saying that "treachery always comes back to its master."

On page 480 of the Report of the Agent of Indian Education for the new year ended March 31, 1813.
Mr. Chisholm, in his letter, writes the following about the mission school:

"The present school is located outside the reserve, but at such a point that it is scarcely less convenient for the mission band on that account; while it could be attended also by the children of the Ranters' reserve, which lies adjacent, should these people be willing to avail themselves of its advantages."

This statement is perfectly true for the present and it will be true for some years yet, until the Indians are definitely settled on their reserve.

Therefore I would advise the Department to build only a temporary school, or an adjoining the Catholic Mission's quarters. A building of $600 or $700 would be all that would be necessary for many years. If the school teacher would find good accommodation in my house after some years we will see what can be effected from the Ranters, and the cases will be definitely settled each in their place of land and then it will be time to go into heavy expenses for school purposes, if found necessary. Whatever you may decide, we want new classrooms as early as possible, as the present ones are too small.

Our present teacher Mr. Polley will quit teaching.
on the 1st April, and I am receiving the request of a female teacher who is engaged in teaching in the Indian schools many years and who has always had the very best reports from the inspectors. I am promising her a minimum salary of $700 = with the hope of raising it raised to $800 = in the near future. You must clearly understand that if you want to make a success of the day schools or the reserves you must have good teachers and to have good devoted teachers you must pay them a good salary. As for my part I think that $1000 = would not be too much for a really good teacher who would teach all the subjects on the programme of study, and besides teach sewing, knitting, cleanliness, etc.

Hoping you will take this letter into consideration, especially regarding the building of new class rooms,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

E. Lacombe

Sir,

I have the honour to forward herewith a copy of requisition I received from Mrs. B. A. Maple the Field Matron at Moosomin Reserve.

This requisition, in my opinion is very unreasonable, and especially coming from a reserve drawing over $4000.00 Interest money per annum.

Before the Department give their consent to supply these goods as specified in list, I would like to point out that it will mean the starting of trouble and expense for themselves and this Agency. The other schools are equally entitled to consideration along with the Moosomin School, and in my opinion much more so as they have no source of income like the Interest money of Moosomin. It would mean that the Department would be compelled to clothe every Indian child in the Agency, and by doing so would take the responsibility off of the shoulders of the parents. My ambition has been to try and make this Agency as nearly self supporting as possible, instead of having the Indians rely upon the Department. I might say that I have never been approached by the other Field Matrons with any such requisition as this, and in my opinion it is not necessary. The Indians of this Agency are in a good position to clothe their children and are not in need of assistance from the Department.
Eleven yards of towelling was issued to this school about a month ago, and since then yarn cloth and clothing and knitting needles have been issued to this reserve.

Re. kitchen utensils. These were supplied new two years ago and were of good quality. They were in good order on my last visit in September.

You will find me bothering, but at the end you will see that I am in the right. We have opened the Murray Lake School for the winter, whereas we never could get satisfaction from your agent at Battleford. We have been sending requisitions after requisitions for school materials and they always have been ignored. I had no option to buy things with my own money to keep the school going. This is far from being fair.

I have made up my mind to have the school succeed or to close it altogether. There is no use of keeping the day schools opened on the reserve if they are to be neglected as they have been by the last and the present Agent. It would be a criminal waste of money.

Now, I am sure that you are anxious to see us get the best results possible with our Indian schools, and therefore that you are ready to give us all the help necessary to attain to that end. That is why I write.

Dear Sir,

I am glad to see that the coming of Mrs. B. A. Mapple on the Moose River Reserve, Battleford Agency, as field worker is going to revolutionize the way and the lives of our good Indians. Mrs. Mapple is fully qualified for the work she has been given to do, and she is taking the deepest interest in her functions, and I wish you would give her all the help she will ask for.

Our first care will be for the children, to keep them in good health, and for the young girls and women who have been raised in the schools. We know by experience that when the women are clean, good workers, good housekeepers, their men have to follow the example, and exert themselves to give a good living to their families. Of course, for the start we will need unusual
preliminary help from the Department. We will start slowly, avoiding all superfluous expenses.

To make possible the work undertaken by Mr. Maple in teaching the girls and women sewing and domestic work, I have taken upon myself to build a house of 20 ft x 30 ft, lighted by 8 large windows. This house will cost me in the neighborhood of $6,300. If it is not asked too much, I would suggest that the Department pay me a monthly rent of $15 for one year, for the use of this house. The house will need some furnitures, or chairs, tables, window shades, shelves, stoves, and two sewing machines in addition to the one already bought for the Department. I wish you would authorize me to purchase these things. I think I can buy them cheaper than the agent can do. The house will be ready for Christmas, I expect.

Our plan is to bring all the girls or young women of the Reserve of Micmacs to learn sewing and making all kind of clothes for themselves and their families. Also we intend to make them
earn some money, by having them make some clothes which will try to sell, either to the Department to be distributed on other Indian Reserves, or to some other firms. It would be such a good idea, if your Department would take some contact with the Department of Militia for clothes for the soldiers! Give us a chance to try and to demonstrate what could be done in this way.

If the experience proves satisfactory you will have all the credit for having patronized the idea.

Please give this letter all the consideration it deserves, and favor me with an early reply.

Yours very truly,

E. Lacombe

Dear Sir:

Last year I took down one partition of the house to enlarge the school room that was really too small. The Inspector seemed to be quite satisfied with this amelioration. Now he finds the school still too small, and wants me to take down another partition. I cannot afford to break my house like this without knowing whether the Department will use it for a sufficient length of time or not.

Therefore, to show you my good will, I am offering without extra rent, the house which Mrs. Maple has been occupying since January. This building is 20ft. X 20ft. and is just as well lighted and just as sanitary as the average of the country schools of the surrounding district.

I have notified Mr. Agent Rowland of my intention of moving the school into this other building, but as it may likely take another month before getting an answer from Ottawa, and as I feel sure that you will approve my plans, I will take upon myself to make the change at once, before the winter.

I will not ask for any extra amount of fuel for the heating of this house; just give us the usual amount of wood and I will supply what we may eventually run short of.

The proposition is fair and I am sure that it will give you satisfaction.

Your very truly,

Referring to your letter of November 18th, 1909.

No. 117334/1, with reference to the Day school (Okanaga) on the Keeseekowenein's reserve, I beg to report as follows:

As to the teacher Miss Maggie E Murray. She has not a Certificate, qualifying her to teach, and as far as I can judge, has not her heart in the work, although she attends the school regularly, and goes through the usual routine. She does not seem to get the sympathy of the parents or confidence of the children. This I believe, is one of the causes for such poor attendance, as the majority of the members of the Band, are very sensitive, and do not appreciate a teacher, who draws the social line between them, so that they cannot fail, but be touched by it. This of course has an effect on the attendance, as the parents who may feel that they have a grievance against the teacher, keep their children at home until the little matter has been forgotten. The teacher may offend in this way, and not know she has done so. Another cause for the poor attendance is the distance from the homes; most of the pupils having to travel two miles and over, and as the majority are under 9 years of age, their parents are not very enthusiastic about their

To

The Secretary,

Ottawa.
their attending, the excuse being the distance, and they think that there is plenty of time for them to go to school, when they are older.

The building is a frame one, 18 x 36 with a Porch attached and is suitable for the purpose and in good repair. The windows might be improved, by putting in larger glass, the present ones are 10 x 12. The desks are very old ones, but answer the purpose very well. Might be replaced by more improved ones, if the attendance was better. There are several large maps of Canada and one of the World, showing the British Possessions, also the usual equipment, in Reading cards, slates &c.

In connection with this school I wish to state, that ex-pupils who have received training in this Day school, in previous years— I refer to girl pupils—and who have not attended any Industrial or Boarding schools, have been a great credit to their teachers. A number of these girls pupils are now living on the reserve and are quite able to read and write plainly and are very good housekeepers. I might mention the daughters of Mrs. Cook, Mrs. Geo. Flett and Solomon Burns. Nearly all these young women have been and are now employed as domestic servants and give excellent satisfaction to their employers.

With reference to improving this school I would suggest that a properly qualified teacher be appointed, one who would take an interest in the Indian pupils, and who would visit their homes regularly, and in this way gain the confidence of the parents. A light mid-day meal might be provided, consisting of tea, bread and butter and rice, during the winter months. The biscuit ration would do for the summer.
summer. Madam,

It is desired to effect some improvement in the Okanase Indian day school, of which you are at present in charge.

Experience shows that it is only when teachers are thoroughly interested in their work that a large enrollment and regular attendance can be secured, and from these points of view results at the Okanase school have of late been disappointing. At the same time the difficulties encountered by teachers are fully appreciated and the Department is prepared to lend assistance to overcome them.

In the first place it is essential to obtain the confidence and good-will of the parents and to this end the teacher should visit the homes and by every means in her power impress upon them the necessity for a regular attendance of their children. The officers of the Department will also be asked to co-operate in this work.

The studies in the class-room should be made as varied and interesting as possible, and the teacher should devote a portion of her spare time to self-improvement in the latest methods and devices of her profession. The Department would be prepared to supply you with an educational publication, if desired, for this purpose.

The mid-day meal is proving in many instances a

In connection with the Presbyterian day school upon the Keesekooowennis Reserve we would recommend that with a view to appointing a qualified certificated teacher for the school (its chief need at present) that the school be thoroughly renovated with a view to making it habitable for the teacher and more up-to-date for efficient work. We would recommend a measure of compulsory attendance throughout the whole Agency. Parents of able bodied children over, say, ten years of age being required in the presence of the inspector at the treaty payments to give adequate reasons why their children should not be sent to some school. Practically no Indians in this Agency are opposed to education. They simply do not care to decide to surrender their children particularly if they are delicate. In this connection, particularly if the parent be a widow, old or delicate, the treaty money of the school children should not be funded. Extract from the Report of Mr. S.J. Jackson, Inspector of Indian Agencies and Reserves, on the Schools in the Lake Manitoba Inspectorate, for the year ended March 31, 1912.

OKANASE DAY SCHOOL (Presbyterian)

The showing made by the pupils present was only fair, and no progress can be reported from last year. This school is in very poor shape, and a change should be made at a very early date. Miss Murray has been teaching for five years at this school, but had no previous experience whatever, has no certificate and no normal training. The band complain that Miss Murray has no control of the children and never visits their homes. The condition of the school building is the same as at the date of my last report. The books and school material are in good order and appear to be well looked after.

Miss Murray informed me that she had to close the school on the afternoon of the 15th, for want of wood, but a load had been delivered by the time of my visit on the 16th. I brought this matter to the attention of the band at the band meeting and they promised it would not occur again.

Your obedient servant

Sgd. S.J. Jackson,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

In reply to your letter, dated June, 6th, 1912, No.117334/1 re the teacher of the Okanase Day school, I have the honour to report as follows:

Miss Murray the teacher referred to, has no Professional Certificate to teach, and has been employed by the Presbyterian Church Authorities, for the reason I understand, that it could not secure the services of a competent teacher, with a Certificate, owing to the small salary attached. The Department has however, increased the grant to $400.00 per annum, which is supplemented by $150.00 by the Church, making the annual salary $550.00. This salary should call for a teacher with a certificate.

With reference to Miss Murray not visiting the homes of the pupils, I might state, that the Chief George Bone, on behalf of the band, mentioned this matter to me, also that she had no control of the children during the recesses. I brought this matter to her attention, and she informed me, that she did visit some of the pupil's homes, but as she could not speak in their tongue, she considered it of very little use for her to visit them. I advised her to keep on making regular visits, as it was a sure way of gaining the confidence of the parents, and a better attendance would be the result.

As Miss Murray receives part of her salary

salary from the Church, she should consider it her duty to visit the homes of the people.

In my opinion, a competent teacher, with a Professional Certificate should be engaged, and should be one who would take an interest in the work, visit the homes of the parents, and make them feel that the education of their children, was a duty and pleasure.

The salary, at least should be $600.00 per annum, made up as follows:- Department $450.00, Church, $150.00, or the Church to increase its grant to $200.00.

Dear Sir:

Yours of March the 1st, enclosing a copy of a letter from Mr. J. D. McLean, Assistant Deputy and Secretary of the Indian Department at Ottawa, came to hand yesterday.

We have been doing nothing of late in the way of trying to get a teacher for the Okanese School, for the reason that our missionary there, Mr. Donaghy, wrote me that there are not enough children on the Reserve to make it worthwhile reopening the school. We were told also that the children on the Reserve are within reasonable distance of the school at Elkhinstone, and that there are no objections to them attending school there, and that in fact several of them are actually in attendance at that school. This morning I had another letter from Mr. Donaghy, in which he states that the Indians had held a meeting recently on the Reserve, which was attended by the Government Agent and also by Mr. Donaghy. At this meeting, among other things, the Indians pressed for the reopening of the school. The Government Agent asked them how many children there were of school age among them. They claimed that there were fourteen—nine boys and five girls. It turned out, however, that two of these belonged to a family that moves about so much that they could not attend school with any regularity at any point. One of the fourteen is a non-treaty Indian and therefore will not be counted by the Department. One is at present attending the Elkhinstone School and another, for some reason, will not attend, so that there is a possible number of ten who might attend. The Indians admitted that unless the children were taken to and from the school there would be no hope of regular attendance, and they asked the agent to get the Department to hire a conveyance to take the children to and from school day by day. The agent promised to submit the matter to the Department, but I understand that he has no expectation that the request will be granted. Mr. McLaren of Birtle is here today attending the meeting of the Aboriginal Home Mission Committee, and he said he believed that some of the ten children, when they count as pupils, are not in a state of health to warrant them attending the school. We may wait it seems to see until the Department makes up its mind as to whether they will undertake to convey the children to and from the School before we look out for a teacher.

Yours truly,

Sgd. James Farquharson.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 10th instant No. 117334/1, regarding the re-opening of the Okanese Day school, I have the honour to report as follows:

I returned from visiting the Keesekoowemin's reserve on the 15th instant, and at a meeting of the band, held in Chief George Bone's house, the matter of opening the school was discussed. The band was in favour of having the school opened, with the understanding, that a properly qualified teacher be employed. The attendance however would be very small, and as the Birtle Boarding school has been improved so as to accommodate 65 or 90 pupils, it would not in my opinion be in the interests of the band to open the day school at present, as there will be some difficulty in getting pupils to fill the Birtle school, and as the matter stands at present, the Indians are willing to send their children to Birtle.

The Rev. W.W. McLaren, the late Principal has informed the band, that the Presbyterian Church does not intend to supply a teacher for the Day school, as it cannot get a qualified teacher, and wish their children to enter the Birtle Boarding school.

With reference to the reserve children attending the Public school, I wish to say, that it will not work, as the white parents object to their attending.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant

On the 22nd of July this year I had a joint meeting of the Rolling River and Keseekoonenin Bands, held on the Riding Mountain Reserve, where they were having a Sports day.

Both the Bands desire to have a day school built on their Reserves, so as they can have the children educated on the Reserve and have them at home at the same time. In my opinion this is a very reasonable request.

Riding Mountain Reserve adjoins the town of Elginstone, and that would be an ideal place to have the children attend the white day school there, as none of them would be over three miles from the school, providing an agreement could be arrived at to finance it between the local School Board and the Department, and also providing they had room in the school, which I am afraid is already crowded.

Both Bands state that they will not send their children back to Birtle Residential School after the holidays unless a new principal is appointed, as they do not like Mr. Rusaw, the present Principal.

In my opinion Mr. Rusaw is very capable, though also very strict. He runs a very good school and gets on well with the children, and the children are well cared for. The Indians however do not like him. He has very little to do with them and is very strict about the parents visiting the children, except on Saturday afternoons. They also complain that there is no place for them to stay when visiting their children in winter, which is correct.

I sympathize with the parents in this respect but
but of course the Principal has to be strict in this respect,
or it would be impossible to operate the school efficiently.

A.G. Smith
Indian Agent

Re: Letter and Inst No 690.

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter covering a plan of a school building, and directing me to make up a detailed estimate of the cost of a building on this plan, providing a new school building is required at Okanase Reserve No. 61.

The building now in use at Okanase is unquestionably unsuitable, and too dilapidated to repair, but I would be sorry to see a new building erected on the plan attached to your letter as in my opinion it is poorly planned for the purpose it is required for.

The size 20x22 is not of good proportion for a school room; the windows are not well located neither is the door. It is exactly the plan that the Oak River School was constructed on, and the only way that I was able to seat the pupils in that building was to order a number of single seats, and when these are placed, I

The Indian Commissioner,

Regina.
am sure it will not provide as much room, with as little waste space as the plan I have already furnished you. There are sufficient desks in the present school building which can be removed to the new building if one erected so no new ones will be required. If new ones were required, I would suggest that they be made with a solid board back, the top nearer level and a shelf placed under on which to store books, slates and other material when not in use.

I have lately returned from a trip paying annuities at Keeseekoowining No. 61 and Rolling River No. 67 bands, and intend to start out as soon as possible to complete the payments to other bands as I cannot spare time to make up this estimate, but I will do so at the earliest opportunity providing you will not change the plan to the one suggested by me, and herein referred to or some better one.

The cost of the two buildings would be about the same.

I respectfully suggest that you place the two plans before the head teacher of the Industrial school, and get his opinion as to which is the best adapted to our wants.

17th July 1847

Sir,

I have the honor to report that the Indian Commissioner authorized the erection of a school building on the Keesawoomin Indian Reserve No. 6 and that when I was there at the Big River Agency Mr. Dickinson engaged George Bone of the Keesawoomin band to put it up.

I examined the building yesterday and found it to be 18' x 28'. It is constructed of stone and brick foundation walls, with a lime wash finish throughout the entire structure. The lower joints, which are strong, are made of larch logs. The walls are of stone, the lower ones on foundation are also larch, shipped up and down on outside, well plastered, and then sided with good shiplap lumber. The inside is well plastered and whitewashed. There is a good cedar shingle roof on the building and corners throughout.

There are two floors of second lumber and a partition across one end of the class-room 7' above the floor.

Yours,

Deputy Superintendent General
Indian Affairs
Ottawa
There is a well constructed ventilating chimney of brick, two windows of 12 lights each in rear and to the left hand side of the fireplace, panel door with good hinges and a lock on door.

On the door there is a shallow frame vestibule 6' x 6' with a cedar shingle roof and a panel door with spring hinges and a lock, and an window of 12 lights placed in this vestibule to make it light. Eight frames have been made on which five wire netting has been placed, thus fill in under the 4 windows to protect the glass and to keep out flies when the windows paint for ventilation.

There are a few minor places on which rustic workmanship could have been done by an experienced carpenter, but on the outside "Bone" done a substantial job, and a particularly creditable one for an Indians.

Dear Mr. Scott,

No.2.

Another Boarding school is greatly needed in that part of the country, either on Snake Plain reserve, or perhaps preferably on some school lands near Shellbrook, as to this the Snake Plain Indians asked me to press for it on their reserve. The I.D. has some nice buildings there, but not enough for a boarding school. It is a lovely spot & a pretty good site for a farm. This boarding school is needed for Snake Plain, Sandy Lake and Big River Reserves, John Smith's, La Corne, Struson Lake & New Reserve, & for the Battleford Reserves unless Union Lake School is enlarged. I think it would easily obtain from 20 th 50 boarders, besides day pupils. But many think that it is better that a boarding school be not on a reserve & that near Shellbrook would be more central for this district. There should be a boarding school somewhere for the Carlton County.

While on this subject I would plead for an Industrial school for Northern Saskatchewan, where suitable elder pupils might go. The Indian boys will not all make farmers occasionally we find them fit for College & a profession or business, & more often for carpenters, blacksmiths or other mechanics or tradesmen. In such cases nothing comes of their boarding school. They drift & are useless for hunting even. In an industrial school they might be prepared for some trade or business. Normal School or college & the best might be helped to do really well in life, & the girls likewise for something beyond Indian housekeeping. The Indians value education more now & are asking for industrial training. Under the present method most of the money spent by the I.D. on education is thrown away while spending a little more would save the whole. See how well commissioner Graham's boys are doing. Wm. Bear (the young Indian of whom I spoke above of New Reserve) who has been through all this and failed to get industrial training or college who is successful as a farmer, is very full of thought about these matters & strongly urges one such school for the picked pupils of both sexes. Please think of it.

J.A. Saskatchewan Bishop

There are several existing schools where rebuilding or extensive repairs must be undertaken before any new work can be given consideration.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Scott,

Dear Sir:

I beg to draw your attention to a matter concerning the present needs and future welfare of our Northern Indians, and particularly our young Indians. I feel that, in our present school methods we are not adequately performing the duties and responsibilities placed on us of equipping our young Indians to take their place in the industrial world.

In the past the great danger has been for our efforts to be wasted by the graduates of our schools returning to their natural and original life. That danger still exists, but it has become intensified by the fact that the natural and original life does not any longer hold a livelihood for the Indians, and as the years go by the difficulty will become more and more acute. The question therefore asked is, "What is to become of our Northern Indians?" Now, as one who has spent much upon twenty years in the Indian school work, I feel justified in offering an opinion, firstly with a view to furthering the cause of lifting the original inhabitants of this country to their rightful place in the world, and secondly, because the encouragements which have met us in our work demand the very best efforts and methods possible.

The Northern Indian must change his mode of living in order to exist. This is evidenced by the fact that trapping and hunting no longer hold out a means of livelihood for the Indians, and proofs if required may be obtained from the Hudson's Bay Company and Revillon Freres Trading Company in their present day trapping returns as compared with former years. Moreover, this means of making a living will never return, because civilisation is pushing North in the form of prospectors and miners, who bring in their wake the mining industry.

This trouble arising from the decline of fur would not be so acute if the North held any prospects for farming or ranching. But it does not, and anyone who knows the North will agree with me on this matter. At our school, which accommodates one hundred pupils, and which is full to capacity, we have three acres of land under cultivation.
This has been obtained at a great price. Not in money, but by labour, for hundreds of tons of rock have been removed from these three acres, and hundreds of loads of earth have been brought in; packed in sacks, hauled by team or transported by canoe.

How best to deal with the situation is the question which must be solved. I am not very well informed as to the amount of land held for farming purposes for our Northern Indians. But I do know that much of it is unoccupied, and that a great number of our strong, likely young Indians are not taking advantage of this means of making a living. Also I am equally sure that these young Indians would take to the farm life if they received the right encouragement. But, not many will under the present circumstances. They would rather idle away the days and weeks or die of starvation than risk the uncertainty of an uncertain change.

My suggestion is that an educational and training institution be established in the vicinity of Prince Albert. Near enough to a High School to enable a promising young pupil to climb in the educational sphere of life, and yet to be in a centre of Indian farming activities. This institution should be modern, and it should be large enough to accommodate at least two hundred pupils, as it would have clustered around it, eleven reserves of Indians most of whom adhere to the Anglican Church.

It should be within easy reach of the land which shall in time become the home of these children, so that a pupil in his graduation year shall take an interest in the plot of land which he shall in future cultivate and call his own, and his home.

One other factor in the adoption of such a scheme. In the Jas. Roberts band, with which I am well acquainted, a girl can hardly marry a man more distantly related than cousin. This is a very serious matter, and bound to become more serious unless we can bring about unions with other bands.

I would not recommend that Lac la Ronge be entirely closed, though I believe it would cause a great deal less anxiety and expense to the Church Society if it were made a primary school with a pupilage of fifty, and as these pupils attain the age of eleven or twelve, draft them down to the new school.
I have spoken to a number of the Lac la Ronge Indians on this matter, as well as Indians of other reserves, and all are very much in favour of the scheme I have tried to suggest above.

I do believe that the farm holds out the best prospects for the Indians. I would strongly recommend that no lands belonging to the Indians be disposed of, but that more if possible be secured for them.

We do our best in the school work, but our best is so often wasted under the present conditions, and it does seem such a pity not to be able to follow up our school boys and girls until they attain to true useful manhood and womanhood. With this idea in view, I submit this for your earnest consideration, with a hope that you will let me hear of its reception, and also with an earnest hope that you may see fit to endorse it.

Yours faithfully

Chas. F. Hives (Signed)
Principal

Dear Mr. Graham:

In a letter recently received from the Rev. G.F. Hives, Principal of our Society's School at Lac la Ronge, he states that during his interview with you in Regina, you requested him to furnish you with a statement of his opinion with regard to the future of the Indians in the "north country". In response to this request, he has forwarded to me the enclosed letter, with the suggestion that I should lay the same before you, along with any recommendations I might wish to make.

The question raised in Mr. Hives' letter is undoubtedly one of pressing importance, but I should not feel justified in offering any specific recommendation with regard to it before I have had an opportunity of carefully considering it in conjunction with those who are responsible for the administration of the affairs of our Society.

The diminishment of revenue from fur, the increasing precariousness of obtaining a livelihood by their natural and accustomed means, the establishment of the new Government Park north of Prince Albert and the probable necessity of altering the reservation of the Indians at the south end of Montreal Lake, the discovery of minerals in the Lac la Ronge area, etc., etc., all bear directly on the question of the future of the Indians in the north land, and indicate the necessity of the adoption of a definite line of action after careful and mature deliberation.

For my own part, I am not prepared to say at the present time, that the removal of the Indians from the bush country to the plains would be feasible, or whether it would satisfactorily solve the problem. Something, I think, is done along that line, and the situation now existing in northern Saskatchewan seems to me to present as favourable an opportunity as may likely to arise to try the experiment.
The establishment of a training institution in the vicinity of Prince Albert has been part of our Society's programme for a number of years, but so far funds have not been provided by Parliament for this purpose. With this part of Mr. Hiven's statement I find myself in close agreement. I fail to see, however, that the activities now carried on by the Lac la Ronge School could well be diminished, and would be very strongly opposed to their being completely relinquished. The schools which are now costing our Society so much anxiety on account of the cost of maintenance are schools of the class he suggests should take the place of the existing institution. Any school with an enrolment of less than 100 pupils is a heavy expense to our Society, and it is the Society's policy to eliminate wherever possible all such institutions by having them converted, or amalgamated into schools of the larger class. To my mind, therefore, any suggestion that the Lac la Ronge School be reduced from its present status would not be acceptable to our Society.

The whole problem has indeed its difficulties, but I can assure you that any help which our Society may be able to furnish in the way of finding a suitable solution, will be very willingly rendered.

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Commissioner:

At your request the Rev. Charles Hives of the Indian Residential School at Lac la Ronge sent you an article or letter with regard to the future of the Indians in the northern part of this province. A copy was sent to the Indian and Eskimo Commission in Winnipeg, and a copy reached me in due course.

As this subject is a very much larger one than the residential schools even although it deals with them primarily, I want to put you in possession of my own views stated as clearly as possible where I agree and disagree with the article written by Mr. Hives.

1. There can be no question now that trapping hunting and fishing no longer holds out any prospect of a livelihood for the Indians in Northern Saskatchewan and Manitoba. The change to civilized conditions surrounding the Indian reserves is coming very rapidly.

2. The results of spending $49,000 in these three residential schools of Lac la Ronge, MacKay, and Onion Lake, is wholly inadequate, and that through no fault of the staffs of these schools.

3. The intermarriage going on in these small bands of Indians will soon reduce them to a thoroughly unwholesome state leading to extinction.

4. The salvaging of the product of these three residence schools is agriculture and taking them away from present tribal relationships.

Thus far I agree wholly with what Mr. Hives says. The point on which I disagree are as follows:

(a) We do not need another educational institution in the vicinity of Prince Albert.

(b) Nothing of an expensive permanent and modern character is needed at all.
(c) I doubt if accommodation is needed for anything like two hundred pupils.

(d) I disagree entirely from the suggestion to change the school in Lac la Ronge in any way whatever, unless it is to increase it to one hundred and twenty pupils.

Now let me outline what I think would fully meet all Mr. Hives suggestions without the drawbacks I have objected to.

I. If it is for the advancement of their children, John Smith's band twenty miles from Prince Albert could easily be induced to move over to James Smith's, Fort la Corne Reserve.

II. On the thirty odd square miles of John Smith's Reserve, erect buildings of a non permanent character.

III. Take all the graduates of these three schools, Lac la Ronge, Onion Lake and MacKay, both boys and girls, and put them into this non permanent institution under a good Principal, with a good matron and a good farm instructor, and no other help.

IV. Survey the whole reserve into 100 acre lots and let the young fellows do the actual farm work on each plot under the direction of the Principal and farm instructor, holding out to them the inducement as a prize that if their three years instruction work is well done they should be put in a little cottage with a minimum of implements necessary to start on their own.

V. While this period of three or four years training for the young men is going on, the corresponding number of girls under the direction of the matron should be doing all the house work, and a sufficient number of four-holed stoves should be provided that all the cooking should be done for the institution in exactly the same way they will do it in their own cottages. In the same way with the washing and mending. All electric appliances and new-fangled methods now supplied to the Indian schools should be absolutely taboo and they should be required to do everything exactly as we expect them to do it in the cottages.

VI. Then bring all sorts of moral pressure to bear that the young men at the end of their course should select one or other of these girls so trained, and start in on their own hundred acres.
VII. The temporary buildings should be only large enough to take the average graduation of these three schools and should be so constructed as to last for the estimated time of filling up the whole reserve in the method described above. In other words the number of hundred acre plots less common hay lands divided by the average number of male graduates of these three schools would give the number of years the buildings would be required.

All this should be held out to the pupils of the present residential schools as a prize to be worked for and earned, and in a very little while the Indian problem would gradually solve itself. We do not want a fourth residential school, but we do want this training school to gather in the results of the teaching in the three residential schools.

It need not cost a great deal, in fact the less it costs down to the level of three instructors and little farm cottages, the better. I sincerely hope that an attempt will be made this coming summer to put such a scheme into operation on John Smith's Reserve.

With kind regards,

Yours very faithfully,

G. E. Saskatchewan

Mr. Commissioner Graham,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:

With reference to giving the Indian Graduates from Residential Schools in Saskatchewan some training in farming and an opportunity to start in farming.

This matter was brought up at the Mission Board on the 19th instant, and the suggestion of the Bishop of Saskatchewan was again commended. This suggestion deals with the possibility of establishing an Agricultural School, at John Smith's reserve, or at some other point, somewhere within reasonable distance of Prince Albert.

Dear Mr. Davis,

The Bishop was here for a few days this week and left for the coast yesterday.

As he is not yet well, he asked me to answer your letter of Feb. 6th, re the proposed Indian Residential School in the Prince Albert area.

He has noted the contents of the Superintendent General's letter to you, and wished me to say that he would not propose the establishment of a Residential School instead of the Day Schools, which are doing good work. But that we feel that the Residential School is needed in addition, and for the following reasons:

1. Onion Lake Anglican School is more than full, and has a waiting list. This school could be filled from the Onion Lake and Battleford Agencies, but at present they have 17 pupils from the Carlton Agency, and 17 from the Duck Lake Agency.

We feel that these 34 children could well be accommodated at a school in the Prince Albert area.

2. At John Smith's Reserve 11 children are attending residential schools, and of these nine are at United Church schools, one at an Anglican School, and one at a Roman Catholic School.

Therefore we feel that this Reserve would send ten or more children to such a school as is proposed, as some of the children live about four miles from the Day School.

3. James Smith's Reserve is sending some 30 or more children to residential schools besides those attending Onion Lake.

4. Cumberland Reserve has 26 children of school age, and no day school. The Mackay School at The Pas was very convenient for them.
for them, but since it was burnt they need a school. Since the parents live by trapping, a residential school within reach would meet the need better than a day school. Some of these children could come to the proposed new school.

5. Lac la Ronge School is more than full, and needs all its accommodation for children from the Lac la Ronge, Stanley and Pelican Narrows bands.

6. There are belonging to the Reserves in the Carlton and Duck Lake Agencies on which the Anglican Church is working; according to the census contained in the Indian Department Report of 1934, 387 children of school age.

Of these 219 are on the roll of the day schools and about 100 at residential schools, leaving about 78 unprovided for, in most cases because they are too far from a day school to attend.

I should add that that part of the Pas Agency which is in the Province of Saskatchewan is included in above figures.

We therefore conclude that the school we requested would have at least 150 pupils without closing any of the Day Schools, and if it were established near Prince Albert, the senior pupils would have the opportunity of High School education.

We also thought it would be possible at such a school to introduce industrial education, in order to help the Indians to become self-supporting and independent.
