Dear Sir:

We very greatly appreciate your kindness in meeting our deputation yesterday and in taking the time in your busy life to go so carefully and sympathetically into the subjects which we laid before you. In accordance with your request we are now writing to give further details regarding the Prince Albert proposal.

We are greatly concerned about the children on the Indian reserves in the neighbourhood of Prince Albert. Within a radius of a hundred miles of that city there are, as you know, ten reserves, namely:

Montreal Lake
Little Red River
Sturgeon Lake
Sandy Lake
Mistawasis
Round Plain
John Smith's
Fort a la Corne
Duck Lake
Chagonesse

On these reserves there are some 400 Indian families affiliated with the Church of England.

While there are day schools on most of these reserves they do not fully meet the needs of the children. This is true partly because many of the children live at such distances from the schools as to make it impossible for them to attend them; partly because some of them lack parental control in their homes; and partly because some of them have lost their parents. Furthermore, among these children who are attending the day schools there are those who are qualified and anxious to continue their studies in grades higher than are now provided by the day schools but for whom there is not now an opportunity. For these children we believe there is urgent need for residential school accommodation.

At present there are two residential schools in northern Saskatchewan under the direction of the Church of England. The first is at Lac la Ronge, some 200 miles to the north of Prince Albert. It is not readily accessible to children from the Prince Albert area; furthermore it is already filled with children from the Stanley reserve and the area to the north. The second is situated at Onion Lake, 220 miles west of Prince Albert. It is already overcrowded and many of the children from the Onion Lake and Battleford Agencies have to be excluded.

Furthermore -
Furthermore, we would point out that the Indians on these reserves around Prince Albert - that is to say in the Carlton and Duck Lake Agencies - are mixing more and more with white people. They are working for whites and doing business with them in stores where Cree is not spoken. This practice is bound to increase rather than decrease. It is important therefore that the Indians, in order to adjust themselves to this situation, should be familiar with English and able to manage their business affairs.

In view of these considerations we feel that there is urgent need for additional residential school accommodation for Anglican children in this area. We wish to ask therefore that provision be made for an additional residential school for Anglican children and that it be located in Prince Albert.

We believe that the advantages of a school in this location would include the following:

1. It would provide more adequate accommodation for Anglican children in Northern Saskatchewan. The returns for this area show that in proportion to their numbers there is not sufficient accommodation at present.

2. It would make elementary education available for those younger children on the ten reserves who, for a variety of reasons, cannot be accommodated in the day schools.

3. It would enable promising students in the day schools on the reserves to have the opportunity of further training in High School grades, and especially in manual training and domestic science.

4. It would be within sufficiently easy reach of the children's homes to enable them to go home for holidays.

We would further propose and recommend that such a school be housed in a building already available in Prince Albert, known as St. George's, formerly a residential school for girls. This building is the property of the Diocese of Saskatchewan. It is situated on a piece of land measuring 250 feet by 250 feet, on a hill overlooking the city, and quite near the Prince Albert Collegiate High School.

We believe this building and property would be well suited to the purposes of the school. The building is of brick construction throughout. The cubic contents are 234,800 cubic feet. It is 46 ft. high and has two wings measuring 79' x 32' and 72' x 39' respectively. It is equipped with steam heating, hot water, sanitary plumbing and electric light. It would accommodate from 75 to 100 children and necessary staff. It is in good repair throughout, but would require certain plastering, redecorating, etc., that would not cost more than $2,000.

The property, as stated, belongs to the Diocese of Saskatchewan. If the Government should prefer to take

p.t.o.
it over, it would be available at a reasonable valuation. If the Government should prefer that it remain in the possession of the Church, it would be available at a rental to be agreed upon.

We are anxious then to commend and recommend this proposal to your sympathetic and favourable consideration. We feel sure that it would prove a great gain to the Indians of the Prince Albert area. And we feel sure also that the service to the Indians which it would make possible - and at a relatively small initial cost - would be fully in keeping with the existing policies of the Government in furthering the welfare of its Indian wards.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd.) Leonard A. Dixon,
General Secretary.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of January 18, in which you and Bishop Martin submit, for departmental consideration, a summary of a plan for the operation of the St. George's College at Prince Albert as an Indian residential school.

I was interested to learn from the records here that the desirability of establishing an Indian residential school in the Prince Albert area has been under consideration by succeeding Ministers for a period of at least 25 years. The limited funds, however, at the disposal of the Department for the construction of new buildings in recent years, coupled with the fact that Indian day schools have been established on a large number of the reserves in the Prince Albert district, has resulted in the postponement, from time to time, of a definite decision on this matter. I feel sure you will agree with me that conditions confronting us at the moment are even more difficult and exacting than the conditions confronting my immediate predecessors.

You are aware, no doubt, that a number of Indian day and residential schools have been destroyed by fire in recent years. I refer particularly to the Carcross Residential School and to the classroom buildings at the Alberni and File Hills Residential Schools. The large senior day school building on the Caughnawaga Reserve was also recently destroyed by fire. The officials feel - and I am disposed to agree with them - that the reserves where these schools were in operation should have the first claim on any funds that may be available in the immediate future. I have been informed also that provision has been made in the 1943-44 estimates for the construction

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Operation of St. George's Anglican School, Prince Albert, as Indian Residential School.

I am returning herewith letter received by the Minister from the Reverend Canon L. A. Dixon, M.A., D.D., and the Anglican Bishop of Saskatchewan, the Right Reverend Henry D. Martin.

In this letter both Canon Dixon and Bishop Martin discuss the desirability of establishing a residential school for Indian pupils of the Anglican faith in northern Saskatchewan, particularly pupils of the reserve in close proximity to the city of Prince Albert. It is emphasized in the letter that there are 400 Indian families affiliated with the Church of England on 10 Indian reserves in the Prince Albert district.

The records here indicate that the question of establishing a residential school in the Prince Albert district has been under consideration by the Department for at least 25 years. Late Commissioner Graham, in a letter dated April 15, 1920, addressed to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, strongly advocated the establishment of such a school.

If it is the policy and intention of the Government to establish and operate additional residential schools, the claims of the Prince Albert district for such a school are certainly as urgent as any other district with which we are familiar. The officials of this Branch are convinced, however, that we should first aim at the rebuilding of the Indian day and residential schools recently destroyed by fire. These officials have in mind the Carcross Residential School (Anglican), the classroom buildings at the Alberni and File Hills Residential Schools and the Back Settlement Day School, in the Carcross Agency.
Ontario, and also the large senior school on the Caughnawaga Reserve, Quebec. The cost of operating the Anglican Ladies' College at Prince Albert as a residential school would amount to approximately $20,000.00 per annum, a sum almost equal to the amount necessary for the construction of classrooms at Alberni and File Hills. I should state also that no provision has been made in the 1943-44 estimates for the amount required to operate an additional residential school. In view of all the circumstances, therefore, I do not feel that the proposal submitted by Canon Dixon and Bishop Martin can be seriously considered at this time.

Director.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of above letter and to say that I have been expecting such an one for some time for the reason that Mr. Clements and others are much in favor of this scheme Mr. Clements going so far as to tell the Indians not to send their children to the boarding school as if they keep them at home the Department will have to build a day school. The Department knows Mr. Clements well and the trouble he has caused in the Wabamun district, without any further comment for me.

The number of children of school age belonging to the Methodist church are 15 and to the Catholic denomination 9 all for whom boarding and other schools are provided.

So far as day schools are concerned I am in a position to speak with knowledge and experience for I taught an Indian day school on the Blackfoot reserve from Jan. 1896 to Dec. 1898 and it is not too little to say that the whole thing was an absolute farce. The children make no progress worth speaking of in their studies, mostly because of their erratic and irregular attendance. Their moral training is impossible whilst living in the camp and the endeavour to inculcate the white man's methods to children under the direct influence of their Indian parents is out of the question, ergo the establishment of a day school on the Paul's reserve would from my view point prove a failure.
That these children urgently need training is most evident but I would prefer to see them in an industrial school and kept there from the time they entered till of an age to be discharged. I do not believe in the long holidays spent in the camps.

Your obedient servant,

The slates, wash basins &c mentioned in above letter were all ordered from Connell & Co. of Edmonton who will send them all in one lot by express to Duffield Station at once—probably they are there now.

It was suggested by me that one of the larger boys be selected to act as janitor for the school to do the necessary work about the place as mentioned and Mr. Dobson agreed with me that it would be preferable to having any one else.

The erection of two closets for use of the pupils was taken up and the carpenters who are now doing some work on the mission house are to let me know what they will cost and later I will write again.

Dear Sir,

I have been thinking of a plan by which we might help the children of this Reserve Day School. At present there is no mid-day meal provided and nothing is sent to give the children any sort of meal or drink except water.

We have been giving them some of our own milk from our one cow. At present we are giving them some bread and something on it besides the milk. Just a little to keep them in fair shape to attend school. They take none home of course. The children should not be punished for their parents' sins. Besides this we believe the food they get is a drawing card.

Now, I have thought if the Department would supply us with a cow so that we could have two cows on the property we could exchange values in this way. Have one cow freshen in the spring, the other in the fall. Thus we would have a supply of milk the year round. When the School Cow was dry, the Parsons' cow could provide the milk and vice versa. We would take care of the cow and provide feed for her in exchange for her use and her milk in the exchange of value. Thus the school children would receive good milk all the year round and in addition there would be some for any sick who might be in need of it. One cow cannot be expected to furnish milk and butter for our own family and the children as well. This plan might be feasible in lieu of a mid-day meal. There is pasture sufficient on the Church Property for two cows and winter food can easily be secured here on the Reserve. Then if we were given some biscuits we could get along very well I think till such time as the school progresses to demand further attention. If this plan meets with your approval I would suggest buying A Jersey cow as it will be milk we will be after not beef or stock.

We would make some butter, too, which would be used on the biscuits.

I might mention in passing that at present we are holding school in part of our own house as the school building is too cold in winter and it would take too much fuel to warm it up.

Hoping to have your thought on the above plan at your earliest convenience, I am,

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Arnup:

It will be a source of gratification to you as it was to me to know that John House, the one who was so antagonistic towards us last summer, is now working tooth and nail for the good of the school here. He was here this noon also, asking for the children who were not coming, and when he was told he said he would go after them. The other people are coming around to us too. We are so pleased to note the change of atmosphere and we thank God our good Father who is surely guiding us.

The chief reason, I believe, for the non-attendance of children was the fear that they would be forcibly sent to Red Deer at thirteen years. This fear I have endeavored to dispel though I have told them that it is the best place for them. We have had a good number for this Reserve, though, Mr. Arnup, it is hard for some of school age to come. Some are halt, maimed and almost blind.

I wrote to Mr. Ferrier suggesting that someone be sent to go with me into every home and see things at first hand. Then both Church and State would see things as they really are. I would suggest someone who knows neither the missionary, government officials or Indians,-a total outsider.

I have been wondering whether if some sort of amalgamation could be carried out since the flu has depleted our Indian population so much, it would be better for Reserves and save much money in buildings. We have had only seven deaths on this Reserve from flu. Three of these were Methodists.

Am happy to advise that last week we had a visit from Dr. John Park, Edmonton, re tuberculosis. I think what he found justified our request. Besides the number of victims which he found, and some were off the Reserve and could not be reached, the deaths since we came up here have been ten from this disease alone. Now, this Reserve is only one and so I am hoping for some concerted definite action.

We are not discouraged as yet with the work. Our progress has been slow but we realize our limitations. We are only ordinary individuals and not geniuses. It is a big job and we earnestly expect your prayers that we may be obedient to the mission. I really think, though, Mr. Arnup, that a school here will never be a notorious success. For one reason there are not enough children. And this awful tuberculosis is making such havoc with the people. The
children are certain to get the infection. I would suggest careful consideration re this Reserve ere anything definite is decided upon. But the school is picking up this year and we hope for better results than last year.

Sincerely yours,

(Signed) Fred J. Dodson.

We have been in the Indian work now twelve years and have come to think that there is a missing link in our system.

Our Industrial School graduates almost invariably fail upon their coming home to the Reserve life. This is patent to you and not elaborate upon it. Could some scheme as the following be carried out?

Secure a Reserve for the graduates only, similar in many respects to the Idle Hills Colony Sect. Such Reserve to be under the direct supervision of a sympathetic farmer-missionary who would be a Government appointee but a nominee of the Methodist Church.

If the Indians from some of the smaller Reserves be moved together, it would leave a Reserve for the colony. Or the land might be secured for the purpose. The colony could be started.

Thanking you, personally, for your kindly interest in us.

Yours sincerely,

Fred. J. Dodson

Dear Sir:

I have just returned from our Conference gathering in Edmonton. Rev. Mr. Newton, our Missionary at Duffield, west of Edmonton, spoke to me about the old log building in which school has been conducted more or less for many years. This building has also been used for church purposes until recently, when the Methodist Missionary Society, in September 1922, erected a fine church which cost about $2500.00.

To the best of my knowledge the Government and the Missionary Society have both put grants of money into the old building throughout the years and who owns it I cannot tell. Maybe you have information in your files regarding this. In any case, I am now making a request that the Department allow us to move the building to the back of the reserve so that it may be used as a stable or shed by the Indians. It seems to be quite clear that this building will never be used again for school purposes and as it now stands, it is not only in the way, but will become a menace from the standpoint of fire.

I shall be much obliged if you will give me permission to have this building used as above suggested.

Yours faithfully,

Arthur Farmer
Superintendent of Indian Missions for the Methodist Church.

Sir,

In accordance with your suggestion we beg to present in a formal manner the request which has already been made personally for some support to the Indian Industrial and Boarding Schools which are to be opened under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church at Birtle and the Crowland about the beginning of November and at the Sile Hills a few weeks later. A large stone building has been rented at Birtle; a substantial frame building costing about $1800 at the Crowland, and a stone building costing $1700 (of which the Indian Department contributes $450) well advanced towards completion at the Sile Hills. It is expected that each of these schools will accommodate from 20 to 25 pupils.

We would support our request for assistance by the following considerations:

1. The
1. The satisfactory nature of the work done in boarding schools as compared with day schools. On this point the Commissioner says in his last annual report: "I am disposed to think that more real benefit has accrued to the Indian children from the expenditure of something less than $1500 during the past year in assisting boarding schools than from the sum of $10,500 which approximates our expenditure on Day schools.

2. The fact that aid equal in amount to that for which we ask, and in some cases larger, has already been granted to a considerable number of Indian schools by the Department. Even if our request is granted, the proportion of aid received from the Government will be much less than the Government gives to aid schools for white children in the Territories. Statistics compiled by the Board of Education show that 7/8 per cent of the teachers salaries in these schools is paid by the Government. What we ask is only that the Government pay part of the cost of boarding the children. The Church pays the remainder of the cost of boarding, pays (etc.)
in a few cases) the whole cost of the buildings, and pays also the whole cost of the teaching.

3. The Dominion Parliament voted money two and a half years ago for the building of an Industrial School for Indians to be placed under the care of the Presbyterian Church. The erection of that building has not been begun yet and we are of opinion that since the Government has been unable to provide us with the promised and needed appliances, we may fairly claim that it should help us to maintain the children in cases where we provide the appliances ourselves. We would therefore respectfully urge upon the Government the advisability of granting assistance to these three schools at the rate of not less than $60 per caput. per annum for the months such schools may be open during the current fiscal year.

We have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servants,

As far as regards "trades" the requirement which you say is exacted of schools of the industrial type is not complied with - and if it were it would be a matter for regret. Many of the pupils in these schools are girls to whom it is not desirable to teach trades. Of the boys a considerable proportion are under the age of twelve years and so too young to learn trades; and further, we venture to call your attention to the fact that in some of the schools which receive $100 per pupil not even a pretense is made of teaching trades.

As regards "other lines of industry," a great prominence is given in our schools to this department; and the utmost pains are taken by providing careful, patient and well qualified instructors, to give Indian children the training without which no amount of book learning would be of permanent advantage to them. Sir,

I am instructed to acknowledge the receipt through Mr Hayter Read of the letter in which you state that you fear you will be unable at all events this year, to provide funds for the erection of an addition to the Crow Stand school.

While we note with a degree of pleasure that you admit the reasonableness of our request in your implied willingness to provide the funds next year, we regret that you do not promise to recommend a grant in the estimates now about to be submitted and I am instructed to urge our request once more upon your favorable consideration.

We have removed the only objection you have alleged against the grant, viz., the inexpediency of erecting such a building on land not controlled by the Government. Moreover the positive arguments in support of our request are strong. We have carried on a school in this place for some fourteen years in buildings provided by ourselves. We have spent $2700 in the past two years in the erection of more commodious premises and for this purpose we received no help whatever from the Government. We have now in operation an Industrial boarding school which has an average attendance of 50 pupils and the management of which has won strong
commendations from the officers of the Indian Department. The future extension of the work which is urgently demanded, is hindered by want of room and we venture to think that our request for $1000 to erect a stone building to be used as a school room and a dormitory for boys, is an extremely modest one under the circumstances.

Nothing is said in the letter we have received about the increase we asked for in the annual grant to pupils in five of our industrial boarding schools. I am instructed to press the necessity for this increase once more upon your attention. Let me urge the following considerations. The lengthy and varied character of your experience in such matters makes it unnecessary that I should do more than mention them.

(1st) Any proposed solution of the Indian problem must treat the education of the young as one of its most important elements and there is no means of education practicable in the North West that equals in value the system of industrial boarding schools. This general principle is urged so forcibly and so frequently in your own official reports that I make no attempt to prove it.

(2nd) These schools for which assistance is asked are now in successful operation and have been favorably reported upon.
by your inspectors. In regard to other schools, even before a stone was turned the Government has in some cases promised large grants to erect buildings and an annual rate of $100 per pupil.

We do not ask as much as this. We have shown that we are capable of doing such work and are doing it and now we ask for an adequate grant.

(3rd) As the case stands now the Government bears a much less proportion of the expense in our industrial boarding schools than in the case of other schools of any class carried on by any organization among the Indians. The $60 per pupil which we now receive scarcely covers the cost of food and clothing, to say nothing of fuel, light and other expenses and to say nothing especially of teaching.

(4th) The Government has already admitted the justice of the arguments upon which we base our request by making grants of $100 per pupil to similar schools under the care of the Roman Catholic Church and the Church of England.

These considerations you will remember I have not only repeatedly laid before the Commissioner, but I have also submitted them to yourself in my letter of the 14th of February. In your reply no answer is offered to arguments No 1, 2 and 3. No 4 is met by saying that the schools which receive $100 per pupil are of the industrial type and are required to teach trades and
other branches of industry, whereas ours are of the boarding school type and no such requirement is exacted of us.

In reply to this I am instructed to say again that in the schools which receive $100 per pupil, a large proportion of the scholars are girls in whose case teaching a trade is out of the question. Of the boys a considerable number are under twelve years of age and therefore too young to be apprenticed to trades. In regard to the few who remain it is not desirable to teach them trades in such schools; they should rather be transferred to the large government industrial schools where with a considerable number of pupils teachers of trades can be profitably employed. This is so obviously the case that none of the schools which receive $100 per pupil do nothing more in the way of industrial teaching than is done in our schools in which the industrial element is made a very important part of the training both of boys and girls and where all the industrial training is given that the pupils are capable of receiving with advantage.

In connection with this distinction between schools of the industrial type and schools of the boarding school type which has been twice made in letters to this committee, I am instructed to call your attention to the fact that in the annual report of the Indian Department for last year, no classification of
this kind is made; and in a volume which contains so much detailed information, such an omission is significant. We would be sorry to think that the distinction is employed by the Indian Department only in its correspondence with the Presbyterian Church and has no place elsewhere.

Mr Reid says in the letter in which he conveys to us your decision about the Crow Stand school that a return is being brought before the House by which it will be seen that the Presbyterian Church is not faring badly in comparison with some others. This is in reply to our statement that unjust discriminations exist against the Presbyterian Church. In reply I am to say that however large the sum total granted to the Presbyterian Church may be, compared with that granted to others, the comparison is quite fallacious if it leaves out or slight the fact that among the treaty Indians of the North West the Presbyterian Church has two or three times as many industrial boarding schools as any other and spends an amount of money very largely in excess of that expended by any other denomination.

The committee has instructed me to express its regret that our attempt to secure the grants for which we asked have hitherto been unsuccessful either in having our arguments answered or in having our wishes complied with. And I am instructed to say
that if what we feel keenly to be an injustice is allowed to continue, we will feel obliged, by laying the correspondence on the subject before the General Assembly or by invoking the aid of public opinion in some way, to make further endeavors to secure the amount of public support to which our schools are entitled.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant

Sir,

I am instructed to lay before you the following requests for assistance to enable the Presbyterian church to carry on its work among the Indians during the fiscal year, for which estimates are not being prepared:

1. Crowstand's, for completion of school building, $1700.00
2. Birtle, for new building, $10000.00
3. Increase of number of pupils to whom per capita grant is given in the Industrial schools so as to make the number equal to the probable average attendance.
4. That the per capita grant be increased from $60 per annum to at least $75.
5. That the day school among the Sioux at Prince Albert receive a grant to the amount of $300 per annum for the payment of the teacher's salary.

Allow me to say a word about each of these items.

1. Crowstand's.
Last summer the church undertook to extend the Crowstand buildings by the erection of a stone school building 30 x 40 feet in size, the ground floor to contain two school rooms and two private rooms for teachers and the upper floor to be a dormitory for the children. This building was very much needed, as shown by the crowded condition of the building already in use and by the number of children seeking admission to the school. The Hon. Mr. Bowring, last June, promised to a deputation of the General Assembly, then in session at Ottawa, that a grant of $1,000 would be made towards the erection of this building, and at that time it was believed that $1,000 would cover the whole cost. By the time the actual work of building was undertaken, however, it was seen by the increase of the school that a more costly building would have to be erected, and even after the stone walls had been carried up to a considerable height the Committee was prevailed upon by officers of the Indian Department and by the minister to add another story to the building and so make two dormitory floors instead of one. The building will therefore cost $2,000 instead of $1,000 and it is asked that the Government bear the whole expense, paying, that is, $1,000 during the current year.
$1,700 during the coming year. The building has the roof on and will be ready for occupation at an early date.

The church has already expended $2,700 within the last three years in the erection of buildings for this school and the Government has not yet expended anything at all.

In an institution so successful as this, where there has been already an average attendance of more than 60 pupils and where another building is likely to be filled as soon as completed, there is surely every reason that the Government bear, at least half the cost of the erection of the necessary buildings.

2. Nirtle.

a. The Presbyterian church has carried on an Industrial school at Nirtle for two years and a half in a stone building which was formerly the public school of the town and for which the church pays $300 a year as rent. The expectation was that the Government would buy this building and place it at the disposal of the church for use as an Indian school and a sum was inserted in the estimates last year for this purpose but it failed to pass the Council on the ground, it is said, that there was not a suitable amount of land at hand to make the institution available as an Industrial school. The building, besides is not well arranged.
for the purpose for which it is being used and would require a large amount of money to effect the necessary alterations, to erect out-buildings, etc. The church therefore asks now that the sum of $10,000 be appropriated for the purpose of purchasing the necessary amount of land somewhere in the neighborhood of Birtle and the erection of good buildings in which the work of a school may be carried on.

In spite of the disadvantage of being altogether too near a town and of being inconveniently housed the school has been successful. The Principal and Matron have secured in a very high degree, the good will both of the officers of the Indian Department and of the Indians and there is every reason to believe that if money is granted it will prove an excellent investment.

a. There is too great a difference in the grants made to these schools and to those that receive $100 per caput per annum. The additional instruction in trades for instance, which the latter schools give does not cost anything like the difference in the grant.

b. Schools like that at Portage La Prairie or that at Athabasca, which receive $60 per caput and a grant of $300 to the teacher's salary are in a better position than those which receive $60 per caput without the grant to the teacher's salary, because in the case of these two schools, at which the average attendance is small, the total grant approximates about $85 per caput which is even more than we ask for the larger schools. It will thus be seen that the schools for which we are asking a larger grant are the worst supported schools that the Government has under its care. The Government Industrial schools, with their practically un-
